arXiv:2410.04264v1 [stat.ML] 05 Oct 2024

Visualising Feature Learning in Deep Neural Networks by Diagonalizing the Forward Feature Map

\nameYoonsoo Nam \emailyoonsoo.nam@physics.ox.ac.uk
\addrDepartment of Theoretical Physics
University of Oxford
\nameChris Mingard \emailchristopher.mingard@queens.ox.ac.uk
\addrDepartment of Theoretical Physics/Department of Chemistry
University of Oxford
\nameSeok Hyeong Lee \emaillshyeong@snu.ac.kr
\addrCenter for Quantum Structures in Modules and Spaces
Seoul National University
\nameSoufiane Hayou \emailhayou@berkeley.edu
\addrSimons Institute
UC Berkeley
\nameArd Louis \emailard.louis@physics.ox.ac.uk
\addrDepartment of Theoretical Physics
University of Oxford
Abstract

Deep neural networks (DNNs) exhibit a remarkable ability to automatically learn data representations, finding appropriate features without human input. Here we present a method for analysing feature learning by decomposing DNNs into 1) a forward feature-map Φ:χ→ℝp:Φ→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Φ : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that maps the input dataspace χ𝜒\textstyle\chiitalic_χ to the p𝑝pitalic_p post-activations of the penultimate layer, and 2) a final linear layer that classifies the data. We diagonalize ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ with respect to the gradient descent operator and track feature learning by measuring how the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues of ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ change during training. Across many popular architectures and classification datasets, we find that DNNs converge, after just a few epochs, to a minimal feature (MF) regime dominated by a number of eigenfunctions equal to the number of classes. This behaviour resembles the neural collapse phenomenon studied at longer training times. For other DNN-data combinations, such as a fully connected network on CIFAR10, we find an extended feature (EF) regime where significantly more features are used. Optimal generalisation performance upon hyperparameter tuning typically coincides with the MF regime, but we also find examples of poor performance within the MF regime. Finally, we recast the phenomenon of neural collapse into a kernel picture which can be extended to broader tasks such as regression.

1 Introduction

The pioneers of deep learning designed deep neural networks (DNNs) with layer-wise modules, crafted to automatically learn representations of the raw data that can easily be separated with a relatively small final linear layer [LeCun et al., 2015; Schmidhuber, 2015; Bengio et al., 2013]. In Figure 1(a) we schematically depict this basic architecture, which is shared by most DNNs. DNNs are characterised by their feature maps ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ, which create a non-linear transformation from the data space χ𝜒\chiitalic_χ into a representation ℝpsuperscriptℝ𝑝\mathbb{R}^{p}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: which are the post-activations of the penultimate layer. These, in turn, serve as the inputs (or features) for the final linear layer. Most DNNs share this abstract structure and differ mainly in how they create their feature maps. Examples of feature maps include a series of fully-connected layers, as in an FCN, a combination of convolutional and pooling layers, as in a CNN [LeCun et al., 1989], including very deep CNNs such as a VGG [Simonyan and Zisserman, 2014], or a combination of convolutional layers and skip connections, as in a ResNet [He et al., 2016], or an encoder-decoder architecture, as in the original transformers [Vaswani et al., 2017], and many more. Within this simple schema, feature learning can be defined as any changes in the feature map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ due to the training process.

It is also possible to fix the feature map – by randomly selecting its parameters – and to only learn the final layer weights. Since only the last layer can be trained, such a network is typically much less expressive than a standard DNN of the same width. In order to reach zero training error, the final layer for a frozen feature map must be significantly wider than what is typical of DNNs in modern practice. For example, in Figure 1(b) we show that even for the relatively simple task of separating the training set of the MINST image dataset, a CNN with fixed random convolutional layers needs a width of at least p=1000𝑝1000p=1000italic_p = 1000 to obtain zero training error. For more complex datasets, much wider layers are needed to achieve zero training error for frozen feature maps. For CIFAR10, for example, widths on the order of p≈n𝑝𝑛p\approx nitalic_p ≈ italic_n are needed to achieve zero training error for a frozen feature map (see Section A). By contrast, if the hidden layers are allowed to change under training, i.e. if feature-learning is allowed, then a width of just p=20𝑝20p=20italic_p = 20 is sufficient to achieve zero training error for MNIST, and very modest final layers can achieve this for more complex datasets. In other words, the practice of choosing a relatively narrow final layer with p≪nmuch-less-than𝑝𝑛p\ll nitalic_p ≪ italic_n and training to zero-training error or small loss means the DNN must learn new representations in the hidden layers that are relatively easy to linearly separate by the final layer.

The ability of DNNs to automatically feature learn has long been thought to play a key role in the impressive performance of DNNs over a wide range of tasks [Bengio et al., 2013; LeCun et al., 2015; Schmidhuber, 2015; Simonyan and Zisserman, 2014; Goodfellow et al., 2014; He et al., 2016; Devlin et al., 2018]. On the other hand, more recent work investigating the infinite width limits of DNNs, where they can reduce to a Gaussian process (NNGP) [Neal, 1994; Lee et al., 2018; Matthews et al., 2018] or a Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK) [Jacot et al., 2018] has also demonstrated impressive performance on some key model tasks [Lee et al., 2020; Arora et al., 2019]. Since these are limits where no feature learning occurs, this good performance complicates the hypothesis that feature learning is a necessary characteristic of DNNs. The theoretical simplifications that these infinite width limits bring has stimulated a great deal of research see e.g. [Allen-Zhu and Li, 2019; Daniely and Malach, 2020; Refinetti et al., 2021; Lee et al., 2020; Arora et al., 2019; Ba et al., 2022; Atanasov et al., 2021; Damian et al., 2022; Jacot et al., 2022; Malach et al., 2021; Mousavi-Hosseini et al., 2022; Daniel A. Roberts, 2021; Mei et al., 2018; Rotskoff and Vanden-Eijnden, 2018; Chizat et al., 2019; Geiger et al., 2020, 2021; Yang and Hu, 2021; Yang et al., 2021; Naveh and Ringel, 2021; Bordelon and Pehlevan, 2022, 2023; Vyas et al., 2022; Petrini et al., 2023; Seroussi et al., 2023; Vyas et al., 2023]. Nevertheless, although state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance for most tasks is still achieved by a suitably optimised finite-width DNN where feature learning must occur in order to reach low training errors, the precise role that feature learning plays in optimising the generalisation performance of DNNs remains an open question.

While to 1st order, the idea that changes in the feature map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ under training signal feature learning is widely shared, there are many different proposals in the literature for how to measure and quantify this phenomenon. These include direct visualization of hidden layer representations [Zeiler and Fergus, 2014; Girshick et al., 2014; Molnar, 2020], or measuring changes to certain kernels that should be constant without feature learning such as the NTK [Jacot et al., 2018; Atanasov et al., 2021] and the forward feature kernel [Yang and Hu, 2021; Canatar and Pehlevan, 2022]. The learned representations, or features, are exploited in algorithms such as Google Deep Dream [Mordvintsev et al., 2015], style transfer [Jing et al., 2019], and transfer learning more broadly [Weiss et al., 2016]. Sometimes, these features are human-interpretable, as is thought to be the case for CNN filters (see [Goodfellow et al., 2016], for example).

We begin by considering the simpler case of linear models, where features are mathematically well-defined as the basis functions in which one expands the learned function. To be more precise, any datapoint of an input dataspace, x∈χ𝑥𝜒x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x ∈ italic_χ can be mapped to a vector or tensor (e.g. vectors of tokens) via a feature map Φ:χ→ℝp:Φ→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Φ : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, a linear model can be defined with respect to the parameters θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ as:

f⁢(x)=∑k=1pθk⁢Φk⁢(x),x∼q,Φ:χ→ℝp,:formulae-sequence𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜃𝑘subscriptΦ𝑘𝑥similar-to𝑥𝑞Φ→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\theta_{k}\Phi_{k}(x),\quad\quad x\sim q,\quad\Phi:{% \mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p},italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , italic_x ∼ italic_q , roman_Φ : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (1)

where q𝑞qitalic_q is the true distribution of the data, p𝑝pitalic_p is the number of parameters of the linear model, and Φk⁢(x)subscriptΦ𝑘𝑥\Phi_{k}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) is the kt⁢hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry of the feature vector. Since the features Φk⁢(x)subscriptΦ𝑘𝑥\Phi_{k}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) are fixed for linear models, the training task simply means learning the coefficients θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Next, we note that the linear formalism of Equation 1 can also be used to describe a snapshot of a DNN at a given time during the training process where θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the parameters of the last layer (for simplicity we have ignored bias terms), and Φ⁢(x)Φ𝑥\Phi(x)roman_Φ ( italic_x ) is its feature-map at that time, which outputs the post-activations of the penultimate layer of the DNN. The difference with the linear model is that a DNN can go beyond merely learning the coefficients θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and change the features Φk⁢(x)subscriptΦ𝑘𝑥\Phi_{k}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) upon further training, as illustrated, for example, in Figure 2.

Since DNNs are typically trained with stochastic gradient descent (SGD), we diagonalize the feature map Φ⁢(x)Φ𝑥\Phi(x)roman_Φ ( italic_x ) at any given time-step with respect to the gradient descent (GD) operator, and define features at each time-step in terms of the eigenfunctions of this operator. We visualise and quantify feature learning by monitoring changes to projection operators of the eigenfunctions onto the target function and the learned function, and changes to the eigenvalue spectrum under training. Formal definitions and further details of these measures are given in the next section.

There are, of course, many other ways to analyse how DNNs learn features besides the schema depicted in Figure 1(a). In particular, this method ignores the details of how the features evolve in earlier layers (see however Section D) that make up the feature map. However, defining features in terms of the forward-feature map, as we do here, abounds in the literature. Moreover, our measures are computationally relatively efficient to calculate, allowing us to empirically explore feature learning from initialization to convergence for a set of popular DNN architectures (FCN, CNN, ResNet18, and VGG) and image datasets (MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR100), and for different hyperparameters.

1.1 Our contributions

  1. 1.

    We introduce a computationally efficient method for monitoring feature learning in DNNs, based on projections of eigenfunctions of the forward feature-map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ on the target function and the learned function, as well as measures of the effective dimension of the eigenvalue distribution (Section 2).

  2. 2.

    We distinguish coefficient learning, when no feature learning occurs and only final layer parameters are learned, from a minimal feature (MF) regime (where the number of features describing the learned function equals the number of classes) and an extended feature (EF) learning regime that covers behaviour between the two extremes (Section 2).

  3. 3.

    We find that upon increasing the training set size n𝑛nitalic_n, feature learning can change from the EF regime to the MF regime. Moreover, the scaling exponent of the test error and loss with training set size n𝑛nitalic_n increases upon the emergence of the MF regime from the EF regime (Section 3.1).

  4. 4.

    We show that the MF regime can arise early in training, even after just a few epochs (Section 3.2).

  5. 5.

    We find that multiplying the output by a constant, as is done to enter the so-called lazy regime—where DNN training can be described by a linear model [Chizat et al., 2019; Geiger et al., 2020; Bordelon and Pehlevan, 2022; Petrini et al., 2023]—shifts feature learning from the MF regime to the EF regime for typical DNN widths where p≪nmuch-less-than𝑝𝑛p\ll nitalic_p ≪ italic_n. To completely eliminate feature learning, DNNs must be much wider, with p≳ngreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑝𝑛p\gtrsim nitalic_p ≳ italic_n for more complex datasets (Section 3.3).

  6. 6.

    Our measures allow us to visualise and analyse the quality of features in the context of transfer learning (Section 3.4)

  7. 7.

    We find that the MF regime can be obtained even on random data, suggesting that its origin lies in the training dynamics (Section 4.1).

  8. 8.

    Upon hyperparameter tuning, we find that typically, but not always, a tighter MF regime gives better performance (Section 4.2).

  9. 9.

    An important body of recent work has shown that for balanced classification problems, the penultimate layer post-activations can collapse to a symmetric and geometrically simple minimal representation, typically upon overtraining well past zero training error. This phenomenon has been called neural collapse (NC) [Papyan et al., 2020; Han et al., 2021] and is closely related to our MF regime. We introduce a minimum projection operator with which we can analyse the phenomenon of NC within a kernel picture. This formalism allows us to extend the concept of NC to regression (Section 5).

2 Definitions and methodology

In this section, we define the series of measures we will use to quantify and visualise feature learning, and explain how to calculate them efficiently. Then, we illustrate how our measures work using two simple examples, a toy FCN on a 1-dimensional function, where the full eigenfunctions can be visualised, and a CNN on MNIST with large enough p𝑝pitalic_p so that both coefficient learning and SGD on all layers can reach zero training error.

2.1 Feature learning and coefficient learning

As illustrated in Figure 1(a), a DNN can be decomposed into a forward feature map Φ:χ→ℝp:Φ→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Φ : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that maps the raw data (e.g. an image) to a p𝑝pitalic_p-dimensional vector, and a final linear layer of finite width p𝑝pitalic_p. We will assume the data x∈χ𝑥𝜒x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x ∈ italic_χ are sampled from a true distribution q𝑞qitalic_q (i.e. x∼qsimilar-to𝑥𝑞x\sim qitalic_x ∼ italic_q). From this simple decomposition it follows that feature learning occurs when the forward feature map changes. More formally:

Definition 1 (Feature learning).

A DNN is said to undergo feature learning if at any time t𝑡titalic_t during training, Φ(t):χ→ℝp:subscriptΦ𝑡→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝\Phi_{(t)}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT differs from the forward feature map Φ(0)subscriptΦ0\Phi_{(0)}roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at initialization (t=0𝑡0t=0italic_t = 0). The feature maps are considered distinct if there exists an x∈χ𝑥𝜒x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x ∈ italic_χ such that Φ(0)⁢(x)≠Φ(t)⁢(x)subscriptΦ0𝑥subscriptΦ𝑡𝑥\Phi_{(0)}(x)\neq\Phi_{(t)}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ≠ roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ).

From this definition, it follows that if the feature map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ remains fixed and does not change during training, no feature learning takes place. In this case, only the coefficients (parameters) of the final linear layer are adjusted during training, a scenario we define as follows:

Definition 2 (Coefficient Learning).

A DNN is said to undergo coefficient learning if the forward feature map Φ(t):χ→ℝp:subscriptΦ𝑡→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝\Phi_{(t)}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT remains fixed at all times t𝑡titalic_t during training such that ∀x∈χfor-all𝑥𝜒\forall x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0% pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}∀ italic_x ∈ italic_χ, Φ(0)⁢(x)=Φ(t)⁢(x)subscriptΦ0𝑥subscriptΦ𝑡𝑥\Phi_{(0)}(x)=\Phi_{(t)}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). In this case, no feature learning occurs, and only the parameters (coefficients) of the final linear layer of the DNN are updated during training.

Coefficient learning occurs in the much-studied case of random features, where the parameters of ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ are set by a random sample over a distribution, and then not allowed to change under training. In the infinite width limit, it is equivalent to taking a sample from the NNGP [Radhakrishnan, 2022].

2.2 Features from the eigenfunctions of forward feature map

To define features, we begin by calculating the eigenfunctions ek:χ→ℝ:subscript𝑒𝑘→𝜒ℝe_{k}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_χ → blackboard_R and eigenvalues ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ using a standard analysis from the kernel literature [Smola and Schölkopf, 1998; Williams and Rasmussen, 2006] in terms of the integral operator T:L2⁢(χ)→L2⁢(χ):𝑇→superscript𝐿2𝜒superscript𝐿2𝜒T:L^{2}({\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}})\rightarrow L^{2}({\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}})italic_T : italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_χ ) → italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_χ ):

T⁢[f]⁢(x′):=∫χΦ⁢(x)T⁢Φ⁢(x′)⁢f⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x,T⁢[ek]=ρk⁢ek,formulae-sequenceassign𝑇delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝑥′subscript𝜒Φsuperscript𝑥𝑇Φsuperscript𝑥′𝑓𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘T[f](x^{\prime}):=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x^{\prime})f(x)q(x% )dx,\quad\quad T[e_{k}]=\rho_{k}e_{k},italic_T [ italic_f ] ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) := ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x , italic_T [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2)

where ⟨ei|ej⟩=δi⁢jinner-productsubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗\braket{e_{i}}{e_{j}}=\delta_{ij}⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ = italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the bra-ket notation in ⟨⋅|⋅⟩inner-product⋅⋅\braket{\cdot}{\cdot}⟨ start_ARG ⋅ end_ARG | start_ARG ⋅ end_ARG ⟩ denotes the L2superscript𝐿2L^{2}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT inner product defined on measure q𝑞qitalic_q (i.e. ⟨f|g⟩=∫χf⁢(x)⁢g⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑xinner-product𝑓𝑔subscript𝜒𝑓𝑥𝑔𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\braket{f}{g}=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}f(x)g(x)q(x)dx⟨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ⟩ = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) italic_g ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x). The integral operator T𝑇Titalic_T and its eigenfunctions [e1,e2,…,ep]subscript𝑒1subscript𝑒2…subscript𝑒𝑝[e_{1},e_{2},\dots,e_{p}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are of particular interest because T𝑇Titalic_T diagonalizes the dynamics of the linear model trained with gradient descent (GD) and mean square error (MSE) loss111Technically, these equations are obtained under a continuous limit of gradient flow. For completeness, we provide a full derivation of the dynamics of linear models in Section E. Then the learning dynamics decompose into p𝑝pitalic_p independent dynamical equations, one for each eigenfunction:

f⁢(x)=∑k=1p⟨f|ek⟩⁢ek⁢(x),⟨f|ek⟩⁢(t)=⟨f∗|ek⟩⁢(1−e−η⁢ρk⁢t).formulae-sequence𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝inner-product𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥inner-product𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘𝑡inner-productsuperscript𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘1superscript𝑒𝜂subscript𝜌𝑘𝑡f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\braket{f}{e_{k}}e_{k}(x),\quad\quad\ \braket{f}{e_{k}}(t)=% \braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}}(1-e^{-\eta\rho_{k}t}).italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , ⟨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ( italic_t ) = ⟨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (3)

Here, we have assumed that all coefficients ⟨f|ek⟩inner-product𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘\braket{f}{e_{k}}⟨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ are initialized to zero at t=0𝑡0t=0italic_t = 0, and that the MSE loss is calculated with respect to a target function f∗⁢(x)superscript𝑓𝑥f^{*}(x)italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ). Note that for fixed ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ, the speed at which each coefficient ⟨f|ek⟩inner-product𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘\braket{f}{e_{k}}⟨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ is learned depends on the eigenvalues ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the learning rate η𝜂\etaitalic_η of the GD algorithm used. The larger the eigenvalue, the faster the coefficient is learned.

In the context of a DNN, the dynamics of Equation 3 describe what would happen if one were to fix at a given time t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the hidden layers, and thus the feature map Φ(t′)⁢(x)subscriptΦsuperscript𝑡′𝑥\Phi_{(t^{\prime})}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) (with eigenfunctions ek′superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘′e_{k}^{\prime}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), and subsequently train only the final layer. This picture is equivalent to interpreting the feature map at t=t′𝑡superscript𝑡′t=t^{\prime}italic_t = italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the one fixed at initialization so that there is no feature learning, and the DNN only learns the coefficients ⟨f∗|ek′⟩inner-productsuperscript𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘′\braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}^{\prime}}⟨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ (although we might hope Φ(t′)⁢(x)subscriptΦsuperscript𝑡′𝑥\Phi_{(t^{\prime})}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) is better than Φ(t)⁢(x)subscriptΦ𝑡𝑥\Phi_{(t)}(x)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x )). Indeed, Equation 3 describes the full dynamics of learning the coefficients for GD with MSE loss under the coefficient learning regime from Definition 2.

DNNs are not normally trained with a fixed feature map. Indeed, since DNNs are non-linear, they can change their feature maps by parameter updates in the intermediate layers, making ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ, and therefore also the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues defined in Equation 2, time-dependent. This suggests we can monitor (non-linear) feature learning by analysing changes in the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions defined by the above procedure. Within this picture, it is therefore natural to formally define our features as follows:

Definition 3 (Features).

Given the true data distribution q𝑞qitalic_q and a forward feature map Φ:χ→ℝp:Φ→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Φ : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT mapping data to the input of the last layer of DNN, the p𝑝pitalic_p eigenfunctions [e1,e2⁢…⁢ep]subscript𝑒1subscript𝑒2…subscript𝑒𝑝[e_{1},e_{2}\dots e_{p}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT … italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] of the feature map are obtained by diagonalizing the integral operator T𝑇Titalic_T in Equation 2. These eigenfunctions are indexed in descending order according to their corresponding eigenvalues ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The kt⁢hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT feature is defined as a scalar-valued function on the input probability space, denoted as ek⁢(x)subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) for x∼qsimilar-to𝑥𝑞x\sim qitalic_x ∼ italic_q. Since x𝑥xitalic_x is normally chosen at random, the features are scalar random variables.

An intuitive way of thinking about this definition of the kt⁢hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT feature is as a linear combination of the p𝑝pitalic_p entries of the input to the final layer, chosen such that it reflects the natural direction of the data after the transform via the feature-map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ, similar in spirit to how SVD finds the “natural direction” of the matrix. Variations of the definition above are also possible, see Section B.

2.3 Measuring feature learning by projecting onto the learned function and the target function

While using Definition 3 for features has certain practical advantages which we will explore further in this paper, the eigenfunctions (features) are typically hard to visualise directly for high-dimensional problems. To make progress in analysing and visualising feature learning, we will define measures based on projecting the eigenfunctions onto either the target function f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which describes the target function on all the data x∈χ𝑥𝜒x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x ∈ italic_χ, or else the learned function f^^𝑓\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG that the DNN expresses once training on a training set St⁢r∈χsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑟𝜒S_{tr}\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_χ is complete.

Before defining our measures, we note that for the sake of simplicity, we considered DNNs with scalar output functions f𝑓fitalic_f in the previous sections. For a balanced C𝐶Citalic_C-way classification task, the target function is a vector function (i.e. f∗:χ→ℝC:superscript𝑓→𝜒superscriptℝ𝐶f^{*}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), and the dataspace χ𝜒\textstyle\chiitalic_χ can be partitioned into subspaces {A1,⋯,AC}subscript𝐴1⋯subscript𝐴𝐶\{A_{1},\cdots,A_{C}\}{ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } by class. The components fi∗:χ→ℝ:subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑖→𝜒ℝf^{*}_{i}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}% {$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_χ → blackboard_R for i∈[1,⋯,C]𝑖1⋯𝐶i\in[1,\cdots,C]italic_i ∈ [ 1 , ⋯ , italic_C ] of f∗=[f1∗,⋯,fC∗]superscript𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝑓1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝐶f^{*}=[f^{*}_{1},\cdots,f^{*}_{C}]italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] can be written down as:

fi∗⁢(x)=𝟏Ai⁢(x)(Ai={x:x⁢ is in class ⁢i})superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript1subscript𝐴𝑖𝑥subscript𝐴𝑖conditional-set𝑥𝑥 is in class 𝑖f_{i}^{*}(x)=\mathbf{1}_{A_{i}}(x)\quad\quad(A_{i}=\{x:x\textrm{ is in class }% i\})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x : italic_x is in class italic_i } ) (4)

where 𝟏Aisubscript1subscript𝐴𝑖\mathbf{1}_{A_{i}}bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the indicator function for Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that because all the classes are mutually exclusive, we have

⟨fi∗|fj∗⟩=∫χfi∗⁢(x)⁢fj∗⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x=1C⁢δi⁢j,inner-productsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝜒superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑗𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥1𝐶subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗\braket{f^{*}_{i}}{f^{*}_{j}}=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}f_{i}^{*}(x)f_% {j}^{*}(x)q(x)dx=\frac{1}{C}\delta_{ij},⟨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (5)

where the C−1superscript𝐶1C^{-1}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the right-hand side comes from the probability measure for each class i𝑖iitalic_i. Then it follows that at least C𝐶Citalic_C orthogonal scalar output functions are needed to express f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We define the target function space ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the function space spanned by [f1∗,⋯,fC∗]subscriptsuperscript𝑓1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝐶[f^{*}_{1},\cdots,f^{*}_{C}][ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ].

Given a C-class vector target function f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a projection operator Pℋ∗:L2⁢(χ)→L2⁢(χ):subscript𝑃superscriptℋ→superscript𝐿2𝜒superscript𝐿2𝜒P_{\mathcal{H}^{*}}:L^{2}({\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}})\rightarrow L^{2}({\mathchoice{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi% $}}})italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_χ ) → italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_χ ) onto the target function space ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we define the quality Qk∗subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑘Q^{*}_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of a feature eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows:

Pℋ∗⁢[g]:=∑j=1C1‖fi∗‖2⁢|fi∗⟩⁢⟨fi∗|g⟩,Qk∗:=⟨ek|Pℋ∗⁢[ek]⟩C=∑i=1C⟨ek|fi∗⟩2.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝑃superscriptℋdelimited-[]𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐶1superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑖2ketsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑖inner-productsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑖𝑔assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑘inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑃superscriptℋdelimited-[]subscript𝑒𝑘𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶superscriptinner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖2P_{\mathcal{H}^{*}}[g]:=\sum_{j=1}^{C}\frac{1}{\|f^{*}_{i}\|^{2}}\left|f^{*}_{% i}\right>\left<f^{*}_{i}|g\right>,\quad\quad Q^{*}_{k}:=\frac{\braket{e_{k}}{P% _{\mathcal{H}^{*}}[e_{k}]}}{C}=\sum_{i=1}^{C}\braket{e_{k}}{f_{i}^{*}}^{2}.italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g ] := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ ⟨ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_g ⟩ , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ⟩ end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (6)

The range of Qk∗subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑘Q^{*}_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by 0≤Qk∗≤C−10subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑘superscript𝐶10\leq Q^{*}_{k}\leq C^{-1}0 ≤ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We use the word quality because Qk∗subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑘Q^{*}_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measures how much eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT overlaps with the C𝐶Citalic_C dimensional target function space ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*}caligraphic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The higher the quality the more of the target function is captured by the feature. We also define a cumulative measure of the quality of the first k𝑘kitalic_k eigenfunctions, ordered by the size of their eigenvalues:

Π∗⁢(k):=∑j=1kQk∗=∑j=1k∑i=1C⟨ej|fi∗⟩2.assignsuperscriptΠ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶superscriptinner-productsubscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖2\Pi^{*}(k):=\sum_{j=1}^{k}Q^{*}_{k}=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\sum_{i=1}^{C}\braket{e_{j}}% {f_{i}^{*}}^{2}.roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (7)

We will call this measure the cumulative quality. Its range is given by 0≤Π∗⁢(k)≤10superscriptΠ𝑘10\leq\Pi^{*}(k)\leq 10 ≤ roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) ≤ 1. Assuming the fjsubscript𝑓𝑗f_{j}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are linearly independent, Πf∗⁢(k)subscriptsuperscriptΠ𝑓𝑘\Pi^{*}_{f}(k)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k ) measures how much of the C𝐶Citalic_C dimensional function space spanned by f𝑓fitalic_f is captured by the first k𝑘kitalic_k eigenfunctions or features. Another way of expressing this concept is to say that Π∗⁢(k)superscriptΠ𝑘\Pi^{*}(k)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) measures how well the first k𝑘kitalic_k eigenfunctions are aligned with f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For a DNN with a final layer width p𝑝pitalic_p, there are p𝑝pitalic_p features (eigenfunctions). We expect that total alignment or total quality of all the features, Π∗⁢(p)superscriptΠ𝑝\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ), will typically increase under training. The highest possible total alignment/quality, when the DNN expresses the true-function f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Π∗⁢(p)=1superscriptΠ𝑝1\Pi^{*}(p)=1roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) = 1. The minimum number of features for which Π∗⁢(k)=1superscriptΠ𝑘1\Pi^{*}(k)=1roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) = 1 can be attained is at k=C𝑘𝐶k=Citalic_k = italic_C, which would occur when the quality of Qksubscript𝑄𝑘Q_{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of each feature is at its maximum value of 1/C1𝐶1/C1 / italic_C. Related cumulative measures of alignment/quality in the context of deep learning can be found for example in [Cristianini et al., 2001; Raghu et al., 2017; Canatar et al., 2021; Canatar and Pehlevan, 2022]. In particular, recent studies [Canatar et al., 2021; Jacot et al., 2020; Cui et al., 2021; Harzli et al., 2021; Simon et al., 2021] have linked better alignment at lower k𝑘kitalic_k to better generalization performance in overparameterized linear models. Due to the narrow final layer widths, the learning problem described here is underparameterized, but the idea that good generalisation correlates with large Π∗⁢(p)superscriptΠ𝑝\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) should be robust.

Analogous measures to those above for the target function f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can also be defined for the vector function f^:χ→ℝC:^𝑓→𝜒superscriptℝ𝐶\hat{f}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{C}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT expressed by the DNN after training, which we call the ‘learned function’. The learned function space is given by ℋ^=s⁢p⁢a⁢n⁢{f^1,⋯,f^C}^ℋ𝑠𝑝𝑎𝑛subscript^𝑓1⋯subscript^𝑓𝐶\hat{\mathcal{H}}=span\{\hat{f}_{1},\cdots,\hat{f}_{C}\}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG = italic_s italic_p italic_a italic_n { over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Similarly, a projection operator Pℋ^subscript𝑃^ℋP_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT onto the learned function space can be defined as in Equation 6. This can then be used to define the utility Q^ksubscript^𝑄𝑘\hat{Q}_{k}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the k𝑘kitalic_kth feature which measures how much the trained DNN uses that feature to express f^^𝑓\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG:

Q^k=⟨ek|Pℋ^⁢[ek]⟩2dim⁢(ℋ^).subscript^𝑄𝑘superscriptinner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑃^ℋdelimited-[]subscript𝑒𝑘2dim^ℋ\hat{Q}_{k}=\frac{\braket{e_{k}}{P_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}[e_{k}]}^{2}}{\textrm{% dim}(\hat{\mathcal{H}})}.over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG dim ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG ) end_ARG . (8)

Similarly, we can define a cumulative measure of the utility of the first k𝑘kitalic_k features, ordered by the size of their eigenvalues:

Π^⁢(k)=∑j=1kQ^k^Π𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘subscript^𝑄𝑘\hat{\Pi}(k)=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\hat{Q}_{k}over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_k ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (9)

which we will call the cumulative utility. It takes values 0≤Π^⁢(k)≤10^Π𝑘10\leq\hat{\Pi}(k)\leq 10 ≤ over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_k ) ≤ 1. Note that typically, dim⁢(ℋ^)=Cdim^ℋ𝐶\textrm{dim}(\hat{\mathcal{H}})=Cdim ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG ) = italic_C, since the entries of f^^𝑓\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG are likely to be linearly independent. Additionally, the entries of the output function typically exhibit similar norms after training. (i.e. ‖f^i‖≈‖f^j‖normsubscript^𝑓𝑖normsubscript^𝑓𝑗\|\hat{f}_{i}\|\approx\|\hat{f}_{j}\|∥ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≈ ∥ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥). By definition, the total utility Π^⁢(p)=1^Π𝑝1\hat{\Pi}(p)=1over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_p ) = 1. The smallest k𝑘kitalic_k for which Π⁢(p)^≈1^Π𝑝1\hat{\Pi(p)}\approx 1over^ start_ARG roman_Π ( italic_p ) end_ARG ≈ 1 provides a measure for the effective number of features used by the DNN. By contrast, the total cumulative quality Π∗⁢(p)superscriptΠ𝑝\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) can still be much smaller than 1111 if the training leads to a function f^^𝑓\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG that significantly differs from the ground truth f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

2.4 Eigenvalues and effective dimensions

The eigenvalues determine the speed of coefficient learning under MSE loss in a linear model, as shown in Equation 3. They can also be written in the following way:

ρk=⟨ek|T⁢[ek]⟩=⟨ek|⁢∑j=1p|Φj⟩⁢⟨Φj|ek⟩=∑j=1p⟨Φj|ek⟩2,subscript𝜌𝑘inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝑒𝑘brasubscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑝ketsubscriptΦ𝑗inner-productsubscriptΦ𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑝superscriptinner-productsubscriptΦ𝑗subscript𝑒𝑘2\rho_{k}=\braket{e_{k}}{T[e_{k}]}=\bra{e_{k}}\sum_{j=1}^{p}\ket{\Phi_{j}}% \braket{\Phi_{j}}{e_{k}}=\sum_{j=1}^{p}\braket{\Phi_{j}}{e_{k}}^{2},italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ⟩ = ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_ARG roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ⟨ start_ARG roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (10)

which shows that they are a measure of the projection of ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ along eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in function space. It is therefore of interest to plot the distribution of the p𝑝pitalic_p eigenvalues as a function of index k𝑘kitalic_k.

It can also be useful to define scalar measures to characterize these distributions. For any vector a𝑎aitalic_a of positive numbers aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the exponential of Shannon entropy [Hill, 1973] can be used as a spectral dimension or effective dimension measure:

De⁢f⁢f⁢(a)=exp⁢(−∑iai∑jaj⁢ln⁡(ai∑jaj)).subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝑎expsubscript𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝑎𝑗D_{eff}(a)=\textrm{exp}\left(-\sum_{i}\frac{a_{i}}{\sum_{j}a_{j}}\ln\left(% \frac{a_{i}}{\sum_{j}a_{j}}\right)\right).italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) = exp ( - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_ln ( divide start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ) . (11)

If the vector a𝑎aitalic_a has d𝑑ditalic_d components, then De⁢f⁢f⁢(a)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝑎D_{eff}(a)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a ) has a maximal value of d𝑑ditalic_d when all components are equal (and non-zero). If the distribution of its components is non-uniform, then the effective dimension will be lower than d𝑑ditalic_d, with a minimum of 1111 if a𝑎aitalic_a only has one non-zero component.

The effective dimension or effective rank of T𝑇Titalic_T can be measured via De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌D_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) where ρ=[ρ1,⋯,ρp]𝜌subscript𝜌1⋯subscript𝜌𝑝\rho=[\rho_{1},\cdots,\rho_{p}]italic_ρ = [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. In a way that is analogous to the way that entropy quantifies the average number of bits for a symbol in the source coding theorem, this measure implies that although T𝑇Titalic_T has a rank of p𝑝pitalic_p, it can in principle be compressed to an operator of rank De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)≤psubscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌𝑝D_{eff}(\rho)\leq pitalic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) ≤ italic_p. From the perspective of ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ, De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌D_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) measures how many eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT you need in expectation to describe Φ⁢(x)Φ𝑥\Phi(x)roman_Φ ( italic_x ) for x∼qsimilar-to𝑥𝑞x\sim qitalic_x ∼ italic_q. As a practical note, because the first eigenfunction of T𝑇Titalic_T upon full training is typically a constant, as discussed in Section 5.1, De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌D_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) in our study is computed without the first eigenvalue before reintroducing a single dimension (i.e. De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ):=1+De⁢f⁢f⁢([ρ2,⋯,ρp])assignsubscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌1subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓subscript𝜌2⋯subscript𝜌𝑝D_{eff}(\rho):=1+D_{eff}([\rho_{2},\cdots,\rho_{p}])italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) := 1 + italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] )).

We can also use Equation 11 to measure the effective dimension De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q∗)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓superscript𝑄D_{eff}(Q^{*})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of the set of feature qualities Q∗=[Q1∗,⋯,Qp∗]superscript𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝑄1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑝Q^{*}=[Q^{*}_{1},\cdots,Q^{*}_{p}]italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. This provides a measure of the effective number of features needed to express the target function. Because the target function may not always be completely expressible by features, this measure can be interpreted as the effective number of features required for the best possible approximation of the target function, given ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ.

Similarly, we can define De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q^)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓^𝑄D_{eff}(\hat{Q})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) for the feature utilities Q^=[Q^1,⋯,Q^p]^𝑄subscript^𝑄1⋯subscript^𝑄𝑝\hat{Q}=[\hat{Q}_{1},\cdots,\hat{Q}_{p}]over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG = [ over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], which describes the effective number of features used to describe the learned function. We expect that De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q^)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓^𝑄D_{eff}(\hat{Q})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) is roughly the number of features needed to achieve Π^⁢(k)≈1^Π𝑘1\hat{\Pi}(k)\approx 1over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_k ) ≈ 1, which is one measure of the effective number of features used by the DNN to express the learned function f^^𝑓\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG.

2.5 Approximating the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues in practice

To calculate the eigenfunctions and eigenvalues using Equation 2 for a given parameter-function map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ, we also need the true input distribution q𝑞qitalic_q, which is in principle inaccessible. However, we assume that for a large enough training set St⁢r∈χsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑟𝜒S_{tr}\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_χ we can use its n𝑛nitalic_n datapoints to obtain n𝑛nitalic_n feature vectors of size p𝑝pitalic_p, and that these provide a good enough estimate of q𝑞qitalic_q that we can use the discrete Nyström method [Baker and Taylor, 1979; Williams and Rasmussen, 2006] to extract eigenvalues and eigenfunctions from the integral equation Equation 2 with sufficient accuracy. We perform singular value decomposition (SVD) on the feature matrix Φ⁢(St⁢r)∈ℝp×nΦsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑟superscriptℝ𝑝𝑛\Phi(S_{tr})\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times n}roman_Φ ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain singular values s∈ℝp𝑠superscriptℝ𝑝s\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_s ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and p𝑝pitalic_p left column eigenvectors uk∈ℝpsubscript𝑢𝑘superscriptℝ𝑝u_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. we can approximate empirical eigenvalues of T𝑇Titalic_T by squaring s𝑠sitalic_s and using the left column eigenvectors uk∈ℝpsubscript𝑢𝑘superscriptℝ𝑝u_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and feature map Φ:χ→ℝp:Φ→𝜒superscriptℝ𝑝\Phi:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p}roman_Φ : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain kt⁢hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT eigenfunction ek⁢(x)=ukT⁢Φ⁢(x)/sksubscript𝑒𝑘𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑘𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝑠𝑘e_{k}(x)=u_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)/s_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that the eigenfunctions can be used on any data point beyond the training set. Also, we have implicitly assumed n>p𝑛𝑝n>pitalic_n > italic_p, but when n<p𝑛𝑝n<pitalic_n < italic_p, we can only approximate up to n𝑛nitalic_n eigenfunctions and eigenvalues. The algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 1.

To calculate the inner product in Equation 6 involving f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or f^^𝑓\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG in Equation 9 we cannot use the training set, because if one trains to zero training error, both functions will be equivalent on St⁢rsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑟S_{tr}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So instead, given the eigenfunctions, we use the test set St⁢esubscript𝑆𝑡𝑒S_{te}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to approximate the relevant inner products as follows:

⟨ek|fj⟩2‖ek‖22⁢‖fj‖22=(∫χek⁢(x)⁢fj⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x)2∫χek⁢(x)2⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x⁢∫χfj⁢(x)2⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x≈(∑x(i)∈St⁢eek⁢(x(i))⁢fj⁢(x(i)))2∑x(i)∈St⁢eek⁢(x(i))2⁢∑x(i)∈St⁢efj⁢(x(i))2.superscriptinner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑓𝑗2subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscript𝑒𝑘22subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscript𝑓𝑗22superscriptsubscript𝜒subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥2subscript𝜒subscript𝑒𝑘superscript𝑥2𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥subscript𝜒subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝑥2𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑡𝑒subscript𝑒𝑘superscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝑥𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑡𝑒subscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑡𝑒subscript𝑓𝑗superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2\frac{\braket{e_{k}}{f_{j}}^{2}}{\|e_{k}\|^{2}_{2}\|f_{j}\|^{2}_{2}}=\frac{% \left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}e_{k}(x)f_{j}(x)q(x)dx\right)^{2}}{\int_{\mathchoice% {\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi% $}}}e_{k}(x)^{2}q(x)dx\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}% {\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}f_{j}(x)^{2}q(x)dx}\approx\frac{% \left(\sum_{x^{(i)}\in italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG ( ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x end_ARG ≈ divide start_ARG ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (12)

In Section H, we discuss the validity and limits of our approximation methods in more detail. Briefly, to check how well our approximation to q𝑞qitalic_q works we used significantly smaller subsets of the training set and found that for scenarios we typically care about, where only a subset of all the eigenfunctions are relevant, this makes no meaningful difference to our measures. For large training and test sets (e.g. nt⁢r⁢a⁢i⁢n=5×104subscript𝑛𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛5superscript104n_{train}=5\times 10^{4}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_r italic_a italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 5 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and nt⁢e⁢s⁢t=104subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡superscript104n_{test}=10^{4}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for CIFAR10) the approximation of the true distribution q𝑞qitalic_q with a finite sample as done in Algorithm 1 and Equation 12 should be fairly accurate. The Nyström method becomes less accurate for eigenfunctions with relatively small eigenvalues ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (typically for large k𝑘kitalic_k). Furthermore, cumulative projection measures such as Π∗⁢(k)superscriptΠ𝑘\Pi^{*}(k)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) suffer from finite size errors when k≈nt⁢e⁢s⁢t𝑘subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡k\approx n_{test}italic_k ≈ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because we use St⁢esubscript𝑆𝑡𝑒S_{te}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation 12. Neither of these sources of error is typically that important for two reasons. Firstly, we normally work in the limit p≪nt⁢e⁢s⁢tmuch-less-than𝑝subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡p\ll n_{test}italic_p ≪ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Secondly, we will see that typically a relatively small number k≪pmuch-less-than𝑘𝑝k\ll pitalic_k ≪ italic_p eigenfunctions dominate our measures. Nevertheless, due to these finite size effects, we exercise caution and present plots only up to k∼𝒪⁢(103)≪nt⁢e⁢s⁢tsimilar-to𝑘𝒪superscript103much-less-thansubscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡k\sim\mathcal{O}(10^{3})\ll n_{test}italic_k ∼ caligraphic_O ( 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≪ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

2.6 Summary of definitions

2.7 Two simple examples of feature learning analysed with our feature learning measures

To illustrate how our measures can be used to capture feature learning, we present two simple examples in this section that also illustrate some basic principles of feature learning in DNNs that we also observe for more complex DNN-data combinations.

First, in Figure 2 we treat a 1-dimensional toy example of a 4-layer FCN learning a Heaviside function with SGD and MSE loss. The advantage of this simple system is that the eigenfunctions can be directly visualised. In sub-figures (a–c), we show the first three eigenfunctions for epochs 0, 10, and 100, respectively. At epoch 100, the MSE loss is less than 10−5superscript10510^{-5}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and we consider training to have converged. Note that the rather dramatic feature learning is reflected in changes to the eigenfunctions (thus features) during training of the DNN with SGD.

Interestingly, a similar MSE loss can quite easily be achieved without any feature learning by using fixed hidden layers, e.g. a fixed parameter-function map. However, when we train with full SGD, the DNN does not converge to this coefficient learning solution, which needs on the order of 100 eigenfunctions to reach our desired loss value. Instead, the DNN changes the feature map until only one eigenfunction, the one with the biggest eigenvalue, dominates the fit to the target function.

To illustrate how our projection measures Π∗⁢(k),Π^⁢(k)superscriptΠ𝑘^Π𝑘\Pi^{*}(k),\hat{\Pi}(k)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) , over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_k ) and the eigenvalue distributions ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be used to monitor and visualise feature learning, we plot them in Figure 2(d-f), at 0, 10, and 100 epochs. For example, Π∗⁢(k)superscriptΠ𝑘\Pi^{*}(k)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) provides a 1-dimensional visualisation of the observation from Figure 2(a-c) that fewer eigenfunctions are needed in describing the target function as training progresses. This reduction in the number of required eigenfunctions is also reflected in De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q∗)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓superscript𝑄D_{eff}(Q^{*})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which decreases from 3.23.23.23.2 at epoch 0 to 1.11.11.11.1 at epoch 200. Similarly, Π^⁢(k)^Π𝑘\hat{\Pi}(k)over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_k ) helps visualise how many eigenfunctions were used to describe the learned function with De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q^)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓^𝑄D_{eff}(\hat{Q})italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) decreasing from 1.81.81.81.8 to 1.01.01.01.0 after training. Finally, the normalized eigenvalues ρk/ρ1subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝜌1\rho_{k}/\rho_{1}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exhibit faster decay after training, or equivalently a decrease in the effective number of features, as measured by De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌D_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) which is 1.61.61.61.6 at initialization but 1.21.21.21.2 after training222Note that this is the only case where we do not make exceptions regarding the first eigenvalue when calculating De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌D_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ )..

For our second example, shown in Figure 3, we compare a CNN trained on MNIST in two ways with a fairly wide last layer (p=1024𝑝1024p=1024italic_p = 1024): In method 1, we fix the hidden layers at initialization and train only the last layer333For last-layer-only training, all other layers are frozen and the last layer is solved using matrix inversion, similar to what is done for linear models, which corresponds to coefficient learning. In method 2, We train the same system, but now with SGD.444The learning rate was 0.05, momentum 0.9, and weight decay was 10−3superscript10310^{-3}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The model was trained for 200 epochs during which both training and test loss converged. Both methods achieve zero training error and converge to a reasonably good generalization error555The fixed feature-map system generalizes slightly less well than the SGD-trained DNN. However, if the layer widths are taken to infinity with the appropriate parameterization, then the fixed feature-map system can be described by a Gaussian process, which can achieve generalization performance that is closer to that of the CNN for MNIST [Lee et al., 2018; Matthews et al., 2018; Lee et al., 2020]., but the projection measures in Figure 3(a,b) allow us to see that the two training methods achieve this similar performance with a marked difference in the quality and utilization of the features. While at initialization, the two systems are identical, the SGD-trained DNN converges to a solution that uses a minimal C=10𝐶10C=10italic_C = 10 number of features, whereas the fixed feature-map system uses all of the available p=1024𝑝1024p=1024italic_p = 1024 features. This marked difference is reflected in the effective dimensions which are De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q∗)=120.9subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓superscript𝑄120.9D_{eff}(Q^{*})=120.9italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 120.9 and De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q∗)=68.40subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓superscript𝑄68.40D_{eff}(Q^{*})=68.40italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 68.40 for the fixed feature-map system, and De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q∗)=11.7subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓superscript𝑄11.7D_{eff}(Q^{*})=11.7italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 11.7 and De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q^)=10.5subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓^𝑄10.5D_{eff}(\hat{Q})=10.5italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) = 10.5 for the SGD trained system. The minimal character of the features is also reflected in the eigenvalue spectrum in Figure 3(c) where the DNN trained with SGD exhibits a much faster drop (note the logarithmic scale), reflecting the fact that the output of feature map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is much lower-dimensional. Indeed De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)subscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌D_{eff}(\rho)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) is 118.8118.8118.8118.8 v.s. 11.211.211.211.2 for the last layer only trained and SGD-trained DNNs respectively.

For MNIST, a rather modest width of p=1024𝑝1024p=1024italic_p = 1024 was enough to achieve zero training error for a fixed feature map. In Section A we provide further experiments exploring the relationship between the width of the last layer and performance for CNN, ResNet18 and VGG architectures on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. For these more complex datasets, we estimate that a final layer width on the order of the size of the training set will be needed to achieve zero training error.

2.8 The minimum feature (MF) regime and the extended feature (EF) regime

In the simple examples shown in Figures 2 and 3, a DNN trained with SGD converges on a solution where the number of used features and the number of significant eigenvalues are both close to C𝐶Citalic_C. In other words, De⁢f⁢f⁢(Q^)≈Csubscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓^𝑄𝐶D_{eff}(\hat{Q})\approx Citalic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) ≈ italic_C and De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)≈Csubscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌𝐶D_{eff}(\rho)\approx Citalic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) ≈ italic_C respectively. For the C𝐶Citalic_C-way balanced classification task, we will say that a DNN is in the “minimum feature (MF) regime” if the following qualitative properties are satisfied:

  1. 1.

    Π^f^⁢(k)subscript^Π^𝑓𝑘\hat{\Pi}_{\hat{f}}(k)over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k ) increases linearly until k=C𝑘𝐶k=Citalic_k = italic_C with Π^⁢(C)≈1^Π𝐶1\hat{\Pi}(C)\approx 1over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_C ) ≈ 1. (De⁢f⁢f(Q^)≈C)D_{eff}(\hat{Q})\approx C)italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG ) ≈ italic_C )).

  2. 2.

    The first eigenfunction e1subscript𝑒1e_{1}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which is a constant function, see Section 5.1 for further discussion) has an eigenvalue of a1>0subscript𝑎10a_{1}>0italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, while the next (C−1)𝐶1(C-1)( italic_C - 1 )-eigenfunctions e2,⋯,eCsubscript𝑒2⋯subscript𝑒𝐶e_{2},\cdots,e_{C}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT all have eigenvalues of a2>0subscript𝑎20a_{2}>0italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0. In addition, all other eigenvalues decrease significantly for k>C𝑘𝐶k>Citalic_k > italic_C (De⁢f⁢f⁢(ρ)≈Csubscript𝐷𝑒𝑓𝑓𝜌𝐶D_{eff}(\rho)\approx Citalic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_f italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) ≈ italic_C).

It would also be useful to derive a quantitative scalar measure of the MF regime. To that end, we first define the state of the operator T𝑇Titalic_T in which the above conditions are satisfied exactly.

Definition 4 (Minimum Projection (MP) operator).

For a DNN on a balanced C𝐶Citalic_C-way classification task, the integral operator T𝑇Titalic_T is an MP-operator TM⁢Psubscript𝑇𝑀𝑃T_{MP}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if it has two nontrivial eigenspaces, one being the span of constant function 𝟏1\mathbf{1}bold_1 and the other orthogonal complement of 𝟏1\mathbf{1}bold_1 inside ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG, where ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG is C𝐶Citalic_C-dimensional function space spanned by entries of the learned function f^:χ→ℝC:^𝑓→𝜒superscriptℝ𝐶\hat{f}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{C}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT expressed by the DNN. This is equivalent to that TM⁢Psubscript𝑇𝑀𝑃T_{MP}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given as

TM⁢P⁢[u]=a1⁢⟨𝟏,u⟩⁢𝟏+a2⁢Pℋ^⁢(u)for all ⁢usubscript𝑇𝑀𝑃delimited-[]𝑢subscript𝑎1expectation1𝑢1subscript𝑎2subscript𝑃^ℋ𝑢for all 𝑢T_{MP}[u]=a_{1}\braket{\mathbf{1},u}\mathbf{1}+a_{2}P_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}(u)% \quad\text{for all }uitalic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_u ] = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG bold_1 , italic_u end_ARG ⟩ bold_1 + italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ) for all italic_u (13)

where a1,a2subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2a_{1},a_{2}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positive scalars, and Pℋ^subscript𝑃^ℋP_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the orthogonal projection onto ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG.

Ignoring the constant function, whose discussion is deferred to Section 5.1, the MP-operator is a simple projection onto ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG. It is easy to see that the operator Pℋ^subscript𝑃^ℋP_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies the qualitative properties above. First, Pℋ^subscript𝑃^ℋP_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has only C𝐶Citalic_C eigenfunctions, and Q^=C−1^𝑄superscript𝐶1\hat{Q}=C^{-1}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG = italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by Equation 9, satisfying the first property666This assumes that [f^1,⋯,f^C]subscript^𝑓1⋯subscript^𝑓𝐶[\hat{f}_{1},\cdots,\hat{f}_{C}][ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are C𝐶Citalic_C linearly independent, which is typically true for DNN trained on a balanced dataset.. The second property follows since Pℋ^subscript𝑃^ℋP_{\hat{\mathcal{H}}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has C𝐶Citalic_C equal non-zero eigenvalues. We note that the TM⁢Psubscript𝑇𝑀𝑃T_{MP}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT operator is closely related to the phenomenon of NC [Papyan et al., 2020]. Indeed, in Section 5 we prove that TM⁢Psubscript𝑇𝑀𝑃T_{MP}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT leads to NC under mild conditions.

Having defined TM⁢Psubscript𝑇𝑀𝑃T_{MP}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we will use the centered kernel alignment (CKA) measure (see e.g.  [Kornblith et al., 2019]) to calculate how close an empirically measured T𝑇Titalic_T is to the idealised operator TM⁢Psubscript𝑇𝑀𝑃T_{MP}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

C⁢K⁢A⁢(T,TM⁢P)=Tr⁢(c⁢(T)⁢c⁢(TM⁢P))‖c⁢(T)‖F⁢‖c⁢(TM⁢P)‖F,𝐶𝐾𝐴𝑇subscript𝑇𝑀𝑃Tr𝑐𝑇𝑐subscript𝑇𝑀𝑃subscriptnorm𝑐𝑇𝐹subscriptnorm𝑐subscript𝑇𝑀𝑃𝐹CKA(T,T_{MP})=\frac{\mathrm{Tr}(c(T)c(T_{MP}))}{\|c(T)\|_{F}\|c(T_{MP})\|_{F}},italic_C italic_K italic_A ( italic_T , italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG roman_Tr ( italic_c ( italic_T ) italic_c ( italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_c ( italic_T ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_c ( italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (14)

where c⁢(A)𝑐𝐴c(A)italic_c ( italic_A ) is centering operator (I−|𝟏⟩⁢⟨𝟏|)⁢A⁢(I−|𝟏⟩⁢⟨𝟏|)𝐼ket1bra1𝐴𝐼ket1bra1(I-\ket{\mathbf{1}}\bra{\mathbf{1}})A(I-\ket{\mathbf{1}}\bra{\mathbf{1}})( italic_I - | start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG ⟩ ⟨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | ) italic_A ( italic_I - | start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG ⟩ ⟨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | ), I𝐼Iitalic_I is identity and |𝟏⟩ket1\ket{\mathbf{1}}| start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG ⟩ is the constant function 1111 in L2⁢(χ)superscript𝐿2𝜒L^{2}(\chi)italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_χ ), and ∥⋅∥F\|\cdot\|_{F}∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Frobenius norm.
