  • Zhuang et al. [2020] F. Zhuang, Z. Qi, K. Duan, D. Xi, Y. Zhu, H. Zhu, H. Xiong, and Q. He. A comprehensive survey on transfer learning. Proceedings of the IEEE, 109(1):43–76, 2020.

A DNN performance for a fixed feature map as a function of width

In this section, we expand on the experiment in Figure 1(b) where we explore the width p𝑝pitalic_p needed for a DNN with a frozen feature map (random features) to reach (near) zero training error. We compare a CNN, ResNet18 and VGG16 on both CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. In Figure 13 we observe that to first order, a width on the order of p≈n𝑝𝑛p\approx nitalic_p ≈ italic_n is needed to train a CNN to zero training error on CIFAR10. To second order, this width depends on depth as well, with larger widths needed for deeper CNNs. We explore a much smaller range of widths for ResNet18 and VGG16 architectures for CIFAR10 in Figure 14, and for CIFAR100 in Figure 15. We observe that if the DNN is trained with SGD, both these architectures can reach zero training error for very narrow final layer widths p𝑝pitalic_p, but much larger widths are needed for DNNs with a frozen feature map.

In the main text, we did not study the effects of the widths of the intermediate layers. One could imagine the extreme case of a bottleneck layer inserted just before the penultimate layer, that would greatly reduce expressivity. Here we keep the overall width constant, but it would be interesting to vary the width of intermediate layers.

In more detail: Figure 13 shows a CNN with kernels of size 3×3333\times 33 × 3, a max-pooling layer with kernel size 2×2222\times 22 × 2, and a final linear layer on the flattened output. The output dimension is controlled by the size of this flattened output, meaning that the number of filters per layer determines p𝑝pitalic_p. When the last layer has p=90000𝑝90000p=90000italic_p = 90000 for the depth 2 CNN, we have 500 filters per layer (increasing depth decreases p𝑝pitalic_p slightly for a fixed number of filters as the image is shrunk by 2 pixels on each dimension with each convolutional layer). Depth counts the number of matrices in the CNN (so a single convolutional layer plus the final layer has depth 2). Figure 13(a) shows that p∼104similar-to𝑝superscript104p\sim 10^{4}italic_p ∼ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is enough to fit the training data for the depth 2 and 5 models, but for depth 10 and for the maximum width, the model cannot do better than 70% train accuracy. Note also that even when 100% train accuracy can be achieved, generalisation continues to improve with increasing width for the depth 2 and 5 models. Figure 13(b) explores the generalisation error with training set size for the depth 5 model at two different widths. It illustrates how narrower frozen feature models can fit less training data to 100% accuracy, as expected.

B On the definition of features

In the main text, we defined the eigenfunctions, ek⁢(x)subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), and eigenvalues, ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, of the operator T⁢[f]⁢(x′)𝑇delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝑥′T[f](x^{\prime})italic_T [ italic_f ] ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). How do these eigenfunctions relate to the basis functions ϕk⁢(x)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘𝑥\phi_{k}(x)italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x )? One way one can rewrite f⁢(x)=∑k=1pθk⁢Φk⁢(x)𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscript𝜃𝑘subscriptΦ𝑘𝑥f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\theta_{k}\Phi_{k}(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) in |ek⟩ketsubscript𝑒𝑘\ket{e_{k}}| start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ is as:

f⁢(x)=∑j=1j=pθj⁢[1ρk⁢∫𝑑x′⁢q⁢(x′)⁢Φj⁢(x′)⁢ek⁢(x′)]j⁢k⁢ρk⁢|ek⟩,𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑗𝑝subscript𝜃𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]1subscript𝜌𝑘differential-dsuperscript𝑥′𝑞superscript𝑥′subscriptΦ𝑗superscript𝑥′subscript𝑒𝑘superscript𝑥′𝑗𝑘subscript𝜌𝑘ketsubscript𝑒𝑘\displaystyle f(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{j=p}\theta_{j}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{\rho_{k}}}% \int dx^{\prime}q(x^{\prime})\Phi_{j}(x^{\prime})e_{k}(x^{\prime})\right]_{jk}% \sqrt{\rho_{k}}\ket{e_{k}},italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j = italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ∫ italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ , (25)

Where Uj⁢ksubscript𝑈𝑗𝑘U_{jk}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will denote the matrix in the square brackets. We note that the rows of U𝑈Uitalic_U can be written as ρi⁢ei⁢(x)=(Ui)j⁢Φj⁢(x)=UiT⁢Φ⁢(x)subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖𝑥subscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑗subscriptΦ𝑗𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑇Φ𝑥\sqrt{\rho_{i}}e_{i}(x)=(U_{i})_{j}\Phi_{j}(x)=U_{i}^{T}\Phi(x)square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ( italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ), meaning

δi⁢j=∫ei⁢(x)⁢ej⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x=(Ui)T⁢ρjρi⁢[1ρj⁢∫Φ⁢(x)⁢ej⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x]=ρjρi⁢(Ui)T⁢(Uj),subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗subscript𝑒𝑖𝑥subscript𝑒𝑗𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑇subscript𝜌𝑗subscript𝜌𝑖delimited-[]1subscript𝜌𝑗Φ𝑥subscript𝑒𝑗𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥subscript𝜌𝑗subscript𝜌𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑇subscript𝑈𝑗\displaystyle\delta_{ij}=\int e_{i}(x)e_{j}(x)q(x)dx=(U_{i})^{T}\sqrt{\frac{% \rho_{j}}{\rho_{i}}}\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{\rho_{j}}}\int\Phi(x)e_{j}(x)q(x)dx% \right]=\sqrt{\frac{\rho_{j}}{\rho_{i}}}(U_{i})^{T}(U_{j}),italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∫ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x = ( italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ∫ roman_Φ ( italic_x ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ] = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ( italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (26)

demonstrating that UT⁢U=U⁢UT=Isuperscript𝑈𝑇𝑈𝑈superscript𝑈𝑇𝐼U^{T}U=UU^{T}=Iitalic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U = italic_U italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_I, and thus U𝑈Uitalic_U is orthogonal. This argument shows that

f⁢(x)=∑k=1p[Uk⁢j⁢θj]⁢[ρk⁢ek⁢(x)]𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝑈𝑘𝑗subscript𝜃𝑗delimited-[]subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\left[U_{kj}\theta_{j}\right]\left[\sqrt{\rho_{k}}e_{k}(x)\right]italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] [ square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ]

where U𝑈Uitalic_U preserves the norm of θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ. This would mean the norm of a perturbation ‖Δ⁢θ‖2=‖Δ⁢θ′‖2subscriptnormΔ𝜃2subscriptnormΔsuperscript𝜃′2||{\Delta\theta}||_{2}=||\Delta\theta^{\prime}||_{2}| | roman_Δ italic_θ | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | | roman_Δ italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where θ′=U⁢θsuperscript𝜃′𝑈𝜃\theta^{\prime}=U\thetaitalic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_U italic_θ. This fact means gradient descent on θ′superscript𝜃′\theta^{\prime}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT would find the same solutions as on θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ. For more information on the importance of model parameterisation, see e.g. [Caticha, 2014]. Given this property, it would arguably be desirable to call ρk⁢ek⁢(x)subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥\sqrt{\rho_{k}}e_{k}(x)square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) the features, as we could write f⁢(x)=∑k=1pθk′⁢zk𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝜃′𝑘subscript𝑧𝑘f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{p}\theta^{\prime}_{k}z_{k}italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the features zk=ρk⁢ek⁢(x)subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥z_{k}=\sqrt{\rho_{k}}e_{k}(x)italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ).

Furthermore, when the model is overparameterised, the solution found is strongly influenced by ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT – so incorporating ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into the definition of features would mean two models with the same features would always find the same solutions. It would be entirely consistent to call features ρk⁢|ek⟩subscript𝜌𝑘ketsubscript𝑒𝑘\sqrt{\rho_{k}}\ket{e_{k}}square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩, and then study its two components separately. However, one could also argue that as the eigenfunctions ek⁢(x)subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) are correctly normalized, it would not make sense to call features rescaled eigenfunctions – two models with the same ek⁢(x)subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) but different eigenvalues ρk,ρk′subscript𝜌𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜌′𝑘\rho_{k},\rho^{\prime}_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would disagree on how much the k’th feature is present in the input. This also seems undesirable.

As a result of these issues, and given that our measures use the correctly normalized ek⁢(x)subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), or ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT separately, we find it easier to call |ek⟩ketsubscript𝑒𝑘\ket{e_{k}}| start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ the features and ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the associated eigenvalue.

It is also worth briefly discussing exactly how the eigenfunctions ek⁢(x)subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥e_{k}(x)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) relate to more intuitive pictures of features – as abstract properties of the input (for example, the edge of an object, or the object itself, in image data). It has been shown in e.g. [Krizhevsky et al., 2017] that early layers of CNNs do indeed pick up on edges, and later layers pick up on more abstract features (like chain links) [Graetz, 2019]. It is at present less clear how to make similar interpretations of our final layer features. Future work on intermediate layer features (see also Section D) may help bring some insight, however.

C Further Experiments

In this section, we present a series of further experiments that complement various points made in the main text.

D Intermediate layer features

In the main text, we only study the final layer features. Analysing the middle layers is necessary for a complete understanding of feature learning. This appendix shows how we can straightforwardly apply measures outlined in Section 2, and discusses the problems with doing this. See e.g. [Alain and Bengio, 2016; Montavon et al., 2011; Lou et al., 2022] for related work.

Intermediate layers have an intermediate feature map in the same way the last layer does. The feature map of the l𝑙litalic_l’th layer is Φ(l):χ→ℝpl:superscriptΦ𝑙→𝜒superscriptℝsubscript𝑝𝑙\Phi^{(l)}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt% }{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{p_{l}}roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where plsubscript𝑝𝑙p_{l}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of features for layer l𝑙litalic_l. This induces a feature kernel for the l𝑙litalic_l’th layer, Φ(l)⁢(x)T⁢Φ(l)⁢(x′)superscriptΦ𝑙superscript𝑥𝑇superscriptΦ𝑙superscript𝑥′\Phi^{(l)}(x)^{T}\Phi^{(l)}(x^{\prime})roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Its eigenvalues, eigenfunctions and all projection measures in Section 2 can be defined in exactly the same way that they are for the last layer. When the output of the feature map Φ(l)superscriptΦ𝑙\Phi^{(l)}roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is multidimensional (e.g. the output from a 2D convolutional module), the output is flattened to a vector (similarly to [Montavon et al., 2011; Alain and Bengio, 2016; Raghu et al., 2017]).

The interpretation of Φ(l)superscriptΦ𝑙\Phi^{(l)}roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as an intermediate feature map and measuring its change with training to monitor feature learning in intermediate layers is straightforward. We use the measures Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*}roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Π^^Π\hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG, which capture how aligned a layer is to the target function and learned function respectively. It is straightforward to simply consider these as probes that help quantify the amount of feature learning that occurs under training. However, more care is needed in their direct interpretation. In contrast to the final-layer features these layers are not used to directly produce measured output, but rather are fed into the next layer. If well-trained early layers are strongly aligned to the final target, that may not be a good thing. We illustrate this in Figure 21 where a greedy layerwise training method leads to stronger alignment in earlier layers, but less good performance than normal SGD with backpropagation for a ResNet18 on CIFAR10.

In more detail, to generate Figure 21, we use a version of greedy layerwise training [Ivakhnenko and Lapa, 1965]. We append an auxiliary classification layer to the first layer, training that system, before removing the auxiliary layer, freezing the first layer, and repeating the process with the second layer. Even though it is sometimes possible to achieve near-SOTA accuracies with such a method [Belilovsky et al., 2019], the greedy layerwise training typically leads to worse performance than full backpropagation. In Figure 21(a), the layerwise training generates significantly greater alignment Π∗⁢(k)superscriptΠ𝑘\Pi^{*}(k)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) at lower k𝑘kitalic_k in layers 1 and 2, compared to full backpropagation. However, the feature quality does not continue to improve in layers 3 and 4, and Π∗⁢(p)superscriptΠ𝑝\Pi^{*}(p)roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) for the last layer is significantly lower than for backpropagation. In Figure 21(b) we observe that layerwise training, compared to backpropagation, has a larger increment of Π^⁢(k)^Π𝑘\hat{\Pi}(k)over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_k ) for the first 3 layers, but a negligible difference between the 4t⁢hsuperscript4𝑡ℎ4^{th}4 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the last layer. In addition, both systems are very close to the full MF regime. This is another example where the MF regime holds for two training methods, but performance varies significantly, as discussed in Section 4.1. Finally, in Figure 21(c), we observe that the eigenvalue spectrum reflects how the standard backpropagation training only produces a clear MF regime structure in the final layer. In contrast, greedy training produces a more MF regime-like pattern in earlier layers, as all intermediate layers are treated as penultimate layers in the training process.

We also study the effect of batchnorm on the intermediate layer features in Figure 22 for two cases where it makes a big difference to generalisation performance. Subfigure (a) shows VGG16 on Cifar100 and (b) ResNet18 on Cifar100. In both cases, early layers barely align to the target function without batchnorm and perform significantly worse than the case with batch norm. This provides an example of how intermediate layers help diagnose the causes of the reduced performance. We leave further experiments and analysis to future work, including an upcoming companion paper on intermediate features.

E Two lemmas

In this section, we provide the proofs of two lemmas that are used in the main text. Throughout, we assume an infinite number of data and the following MSE loss.

𝐋=∫χ(f⁢(x)−f∗⁢(x))2⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x𝐋subscript𝜒superscript𝑓𝑥superscript𝑓𝑥2𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\mathbf{L}=\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{% 0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0% pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\left(f(x)-f^{*}(x)\right)^{2}q(x)dxbold_L = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (27)
Lemma 1.

The Gradient Flow (GF) dynamics of a linear model of the following form f⁢(x)=∑i=1pθi⁢Φi⁢(x)𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖𝑥f(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{p}\theta_{i}\Phi_{i}(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) is diagonalized into the following p𝑝pitalic_p independent equations:

⟨f|ek⟩⁢(t)=⟨f∗|ek⟩⁢(1−e−η⁢ρk⁢t),inner-product𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘𝑡inner-productsuperscript𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘1superscript𝑒𝜂subscript𝜌𝑘𝑡\braket{f}{e_{k}}(t)=\braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}}(1-e^{-\eta\rho_{k}t}),⟨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ( italic_t ) = ⟨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (28)

where ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of the intergral operator T𝑇Titalic_T (Equation 2), and η𝜂\etaitalic_η is the learning rate.

Proof  By using the gradient descent equation (d⁢θid⁢t=−η⁢d⁢𝐋d⁢θi𝑑subscript𝜃𝑖𝑑𝑡𝜂𝑑𝐋𝑑subscript𝜃𝑖\frac{d\theta_{i}}{dt}=-\eta\frac{d\mathbf{L}}{d\theta_{i}}divide start_ARG italic_d italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG = - italic_η divide start_ARG italic_d bold_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG), we can write the change of f𝑓fitalic_f as

d⁢fd⁢t⁢(x′)𝑑𝑓𝑑𝑡superscript𝑥′\displaystyle\frac{df}{dt}(x^{\prime})divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =∑ipd⁢θid⁢t⁢Φi⁢(x′)=∑ip−η⁢d⁢𝐋d⁢θi⁢Φi⁢(x′)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑝𝑑subscript𝜃𝑖𝑑𝑡subscriptΦ𝑖superscript𝑥′superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑝𝜂𝑑𝐋𝑑subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptΦ𝑖superscript𝑥′\displaystyle=\sum_{i}^{p}\frac{d\theta_{i}}{dt}\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})=\sum_{i}^% {p}-\eta\frac{d\mathbf{L}}{d\theta_{i}}\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_d italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η divide start_ARG italic_d bold_L end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (29)
=−2⁢η⁢∫χ(f⁢(x)−f∗⁢(x))⁢∑ipd⁢fd⁢θi⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢d⁢x⁢Φi⁢(x′)absent2𝜂subscript𝜒𝑓𝑥superscript𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑝𝑑𝑓𝑑subscript𝜃𝑖𝑥𝑞𝑥𝑑𝑥subscriptΦ𝑖superscript𝑥′\displaystyle=-2\eta\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\left(f(x)-f^{*}(x)\right)\sum_{i}% ^{p}\frac{df}{d\theta_{i}}(x)q(x)dx\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})= - 2 italic_η ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_d italic_f end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (30)
=−2⁢η⁢∫χ(f⁢(x)−f∗⁢(x))⁢∑ipΦi⁢(x)⁢Φi⁢(x′)⁢q⁢(x)⁢d⁢xabsent2𝜂subscript𝜒𝑓𝑥superscript𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑝subscriptΦ𝑖𝑥subscriptΦ𝑖superscript𝑥′𝑞𝑥𝑑𝑥\displaystyle=-2\eta\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\left(f(x)-f^{*}(x)\right)\sum_{i}% ^{p}\Phi_{i}(x)\Phi_{i}(x^{\prime})q(x)dx= - 2 italic_η ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (31)
=−2⁢η⁢T⁢[f−f∗]⁢(x′)absent2𝜂𝑇delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝑓superscript𝑥′\displaystyle=-2\eta T\left[f-f^{*}\right](x^{\prime})= - 2 italic_η italic_T [ italic_f - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (32)

The equation mimics the form of a matrix differential equation. If we take the inner product of both sides with eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

d⁢⟨ek|f⟩d⁢t𝑑inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑓𝑑𝑡\displaystyle\frac{d\braket{e_{k}}{f}}{dt}divide start_ARG italic_d ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ⟩ end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG =−2⁢η⁢⟨ek|T⁢[f−f∗]⟩absent2𝜂inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑇delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝑓\displaystyle=-2\eta\braket{e_{k}}{T\left[f-f^{*}\right]}= - 2 italic_η ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T [ italic_f - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] end_ARG ⟩ (33)
=−2⁢η⁢ρk⁢(⟨ek|f⟩−⟨ek|f∗⟩),absent2𝜂subscript𝜌𝑘inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑓inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘superscript𝑓\displaystyle=-2\eta\rho_{k}\left(\braket{e_{k}}{f}-\braket{e_{k}}{f^{*}}% \right),= - 2 italic_η italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ⟩ - ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ) , (34)

where we used that fact that T𝑇Titalic_T is symmetric operator and T⁢[ek]=ρk⁢ek𝑇delimited-[]subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘T[e_{k}]=\rho_{k}e_{k}italic_T [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Solving the differential equation for ⟨ek|f⟩inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑓\braket{e_{k}}{f}⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ⟩ with initial condition of ⟨ek|f⟩⁢(0)=0inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑓00\braket{e_{k}}{f}(0)=0⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ⟩ ( 0 ) = 0 leads to

⟨f|ek⟩⁢(t)=⟨f∗|ek⟩⁢(1−e−η⁢ρk⁢t).inner-product𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘𝑡inner-productsuperscript𝑓subscript𝑒𝑘1superscript𝑒𝜂subscript𝜌𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\braket{f}{e_{k}}(t)=\braket{f^{*}}{e_{k}}(1-e^{-\eta\rho_{k}t}).⟨ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ( italic_t ) = ⟨ start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (35)

 

Lemma 2.

When T=TM⁢P𝑇subscript𝑇𝑀𝑃T=T_{MP}italic_T = italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a DNN, there is one-to-one mapping between Φ⁢(x)Φ𝑥\Phi(x)roman_Φ ( italic_x ) and f^⁢(x)^𝑓𝑥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) on the support of q𝑞qitalic_q.

Proof  The MP operator, by definition, maps from the expressed function space ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG to ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG. The entries of the feature map [Φ1,⋯,Φp]subscriptΦ1⋯subscriptΦ𝑝[\Phi_{1},\cdots,\Phi_{p}][ roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] span ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG, and entries of the expressed function ([f^1,⋯,f^C]subscript^𝑓1⋯subscript^𝑓𝐶[\hat{f}_{1},\cdots,\hat{f}_{C}][ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]), by definition, also span ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG. Since Φ⁢(x)Φ𝑥\Phi(x)roman_Φ ( italic_x ) and f^⁢(x)^𝑓𝑥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) are related by a linear transform – ignoring the bias term as constant function is in ℋ^^ℋ\hat{\mathcal{H}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_H end_ARG – the map between Φ⁢(x)Φ𝑥\Phi(x)roman_Φ ( italic_x ) and f^⁢(x)^𝑓𝑥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) is one-to-one.

Assuming our input x𝑥xitalic_x is a discrete random variable, Φ⁢(x)Φ𝑥\Phi(x)roman_Φ ( italic_x ) and f^⁢(x)^𝑓𝑥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) are also discrete random variables. The one-to-one relationship then is sufficient to prove that mutual information between two random variables is 0 (i.e. I⁢(Φ⁢(x);f^⁢(x))=0𝐼Φ𝑥^𝑓𝑥0I(\Phi(x);\hat{f}(x))=0italic_I ( roman_Φ ( italic_x ) ; over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) ) = 0).  

F Proofs related to Neural Collapse

In this section, we state the relevant terms and the four NC conditions given in [Han et al., 2021]. Please note that the current study assumes column-vectors for all vectors (e.g. μi∈ℝp×1subscript𝜇𝑖superscriptℝ𝑝1\mu_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times 1}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). The last layer can be defined in the following manner

f^i⁢(x)=wiT⁢Φ⁢(x)+bisubscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖\hat{f}_{i}(x)=w_{i}^{T}\Phi(x)+b_{i}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (36)

where wi∈ℝp×1subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptℝ𝑝1w_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times 1}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the parameter of the last that projects the feature onto the it⁢hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry of the output function. bi∈ℝsubscript𝑏𝑖ℝb_{i}\in\mathbb{R}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R is the corresponding bias term. The feature class mean or the mean of features with label i𝑖iitalic_i is

μi=Cn⁢∑x(j)∈AiΦ⁢(x(j)).subscript𝜇𝑖𝐶𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝐴𝑖Φsuperscript𝑥𝑗\mu_{i}=\frac{C}{n}\sum_{x^{(j)}\in A_{i}}\Phi(x^{(j)}).italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_C end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (37)

The global mean is

μg=1C⁢∑iCμi.subscript𝜇𝑔1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐶subscript𝜇𝑖\mu_{g}=\frac{1}{C}\sum_{i}^{C}\mu_{i}.italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (38)

The feature within-class covariance ΣW∈ℝp×psubscriptΣ𝑊superscriptℝ𝑝𝑝\Sigma_{W}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times p}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is

ΣW:=1n⁢∑iC∑x(j)∈Ai(hi⁢(x(j))−μi)⁢(hi⁢(x(j))−μi)T.assignsubscriptΣ𝑊1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝐴𝑖subscriptℎ𝑖superscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖superscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑇\Sigma_{W}:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}^{C}\sum_{x^{(j)}\in A_{i}}(h_{i}(x^{(j)})-\mu_% {i})(h_{i}(x^{(j)})-\mu_{i})^{T}.roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (39)

The feature between-class covariance Σb∈ℝp×psubscriptΣ𝑏superscriptℝ𝑝𝑝\Sigma_{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times p}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is

Σb:=1C⁢∑iC(μi−μg)⁢(μi−μg)T.assignsubscriptΣ𝑏1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐶subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑔superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑔𝑇\Sigma_{b}:=\frac{1}{C}\sum_{i}^{C}(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})^{T}.roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (40)

The four NC conditions are the following Papyan et al. [2020]:

  1. 1.

    Within class variance tends to 0

    ΣW⁢ΣbT→0→subscriptΣ𝑊superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑏𝑇0\Sigma_{W}\Sigma_{b}^{T}\rightarrow 0roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → 0 (41)
  2. 2.

    Convergence to simplex ETF

    (μi−μg)T⁢(μj−μg)‖(μi−μg)‖2⁢‖(μj−μg)‖2→C⁢δi⁢j−1C−1→superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑔𝑇subscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔subscriptnormsubscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑔2subscriptnormsubscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔2𝐶subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗1𝐶1\frac{(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})^{T}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})}{\|(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})\|_{2}\|(\mu_% {j}-\mu_{g})\|_{2}}\rightarrow\frac{C\delta_{ij}-1}{C-1}divide start_ARG ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∥ ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG → divide start_ARG italic_C italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C - 1 end_ARG (42)
  3. 3.

    Convergence to self duality

    wi‖wi‖2−μi−μg‖(μi−μg)‖2→0→subscript𝑤𝑖subscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑖2subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑔subscriptnormsubscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑔20\frac{w_{i}}{\|w_{i}\|_{2}}-\frac{\mu_{i}-\mu_{g}}{\|(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})\|_{2}}\rightarrow 0divide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG → 0 (43)
  4. 4.

    Simplification to nearest class center

    arg⁡maxi⁡wi⁢Φ⁢(x)+bi→arg⁡mini⁡‖Φ⁢(x)−μi‖2→subscript𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖Φ𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝑖subscriptnormΦ𝑥subscript𝜇𝑖2\arg\max_{i}w_{i}\Phi(x)+b_{i}\rightarrow\arg\min_{i}\|\Phi(x)-\mu_{i}\|_{2}roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ roman_Φ ( italic_x ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (44)

See 1

Proof  By the definition of indicator functions of equal partitions,

⟨f^i|f^j⟩=1C⁢δi⁢j,∑iCf^i=𝟏,⟨𝟏|f^j⟩=1Cformulae-sequenceinner-productsubscript^𝑓𝑖subscript^𝑓𝑗1𝐶subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑖1inner-product1subscript^𝑓𝑗1𝐶\braket{\hat{f}_{i}}{\hat{f}_{j}}=\frac{1}{C}\delta_{ij},\quad\quad\sum_{i}^{C% }\hat{f}_{i}=\mathbf{1},\quad\quad\braket{\mathbf{1}}{\hat{f}_{j}}=\frac{1}{C}⟨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_1 , ⟨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG (45)

Since C⁢f^j−𝟏𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 is orthogonal to 𝟏1\mathbf{1}bold_1,

TM⁢P⁢[C⁢f^j−𝟏]=a2⁢(C⁢f^j−𝟏)subscript𝑇𝑀𝑃delimited-[]𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1subscript𝑎2𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1T_{MP}[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]=a_{2}(C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1})italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ) (46)

where we used the definition of MP operators Equation 13. Then from Equation 45 and Equation 46,

⟨C⁢𝐟i|TM⁢P⁢[C⁢f^j−𝟏]⟩=a2⁢⟨C⁢𝐟i|C⁢f^j−𝟏⟩=a2⁢(C⁢δi⁢j−𝟏)inner-product𝐶subscript𝐟𝑖subscript𝑇𝑀𝑃delimited-[]𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1subscript𝑎2inner-product𝐶subscript𝐟𝑖𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1subscript𝑎2𝐶subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗1\braket{C\mathbf{f}_{i}}{T_{MP}[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]}=a_{2}\braket{C% \mathbf{f}_{i}}{C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}}=a_{2}(C\delta_{ij}-\mathbf{1})\\ ⟨ start_ARG italic_C bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] end_ARG ⟩ = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG italic_C bold_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 end_ARG ⟩ = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_C italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ) (47)

Likewise,

⟨𝟏|TM⁢P⁢[C⁢f^j−𝟏]⟩=a2⁢⟨𝟏|C⁢f^j−𝟏⟩=0.inner-product1subscript𝑇𝑀𝑃delimited-[]𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1subscript𝑎2inner-product1𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗10\braket{\mathbf{1}}{T_{MP}[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]}=a_{2}\braket{\mathbf{1}}{% C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}}=0.\\ ⟨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] end_ARG ⟩ = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG bold_1 end_ARG | start_ARG italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 end_ARG ⟩ = 0 . (48)

 

See 3

Proof  From the translation of class mean function Equation 21,

μiT⁢μjsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑇subscript𝜇𝑗\displaystyle\mu_{i}^{T}\mu_{j}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =C2⁢(∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢Φ⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x)T⁢∫χf^j⁢(x′)⁢Φ⁢(x′)⁢q⁢(x′)⁢𝑑x′absentsuperscript𝐶2superscriptsubscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥Φ𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥𝑇subscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑗superscript𝑥′Φsuperscript𝑥′𝑞superscript𝑥′differential-dsuperscript𝑥′\displaystyle=C^{2}\left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi% $}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)\Phi(x)q(x)dx\right)% ^{T}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{j}(x^{\prime})\Phi(x^{\prime})q(x^{\prime})% dx^{\prime}= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_Φ ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (49)
=C2⁢∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢∫χΦ⁢(x)T⁢Φ⁢(x′)⁢f^j⁢(x′)⁢q⁢(x′)⁢𝑑x′⁢𝑑xabsentsuperscript𝐶2subscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑞𝑥subscript𝜒Φsuperscript𝑥𝑇Φsuperscript𝑥′subscript^𝑓𝑗superscript𝑥′𝑞superscript𝑥′differential-dsuperscript𝑥′differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=C^{2}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)\int_{% \mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x^{\prime})\hat{f}_{j}(x^{\prime})q(% x^{\prime})dx^{\prime}dx= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_x (50)
=C2⁢∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢T⁢[f^j]⁢(x)⁢𝑑xabsentsuperscript𝐶2subscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑞𝑥𝑇delimited-[]subscript^𝑓𝑗𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=C^{2}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)T[\hat{f}_{j}](x% )dx= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_T [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (51)
=C2⁢⟨f^i,T⁢[f^j]⟩.absentsuperscript𝐶2expectationsubscript^𝑓𝑖𝑇delimited-[]subscript^𝑓𝑗\displaystyle=C^{2}\braket{\hat{f}_{i},T[\hat{f}_{j}]}.= italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG ⟩ . (52)

Likewise, using Equation 20, we get

μiT⁢μgsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑇subscript𝜇𝑔\displaystyle\mu_{i}^{T}\mu_{g}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =C⁢(∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢Φ⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x)T⁢∫χΦ⁢(x′)⁢q⁢(x′)⁢𝑑x′absent𝐶superscriptsubscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥Φ𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥𝑇subscript𝜒Φsuperscript𝑥′𝑞superscript𝑥′differential-dsuperscript𝑥′\displaystyle=C\left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)\Phi(x)q(x)dx\right)% ^{T}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{% $\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x^{\prime})q(x^{\prime})dx^{\prime}= italic_C ( ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_Φ ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (53)
=C⁢∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢∫χΦ⁢(x)T⁢Φ⁢(x′)⁢q⁢(x′)⁢𝑑x′⁢𝑑xabsent𝐶subscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑞𝑥subscript𝜒Φsuperscript𝑥𝑇Φsuperscript𝑥′𝑞superscript𝑥′differential-dsuperscript𝑥′differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=C\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)\int_{% \mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x^{\prime})q(x^{\prime})dx^{\prime}dx= italic_C ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_x (54)
=C⁢∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢T⁢[𝟏]⁢(x)⁢𝑑xabsent𝐶subscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑞𝑥𝑇delimited-[]1𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=C\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{% \raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)q(x)T[\mathbf{1}](x)dx= italic_C ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_T [ bold_1 ] ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (55)
=C⁢⟨f^i,T⁢[𝟏]⟩.absent𝐶expectationsubscript^𝑓𝑖𝑇delimited-[]1\displaystyle=C\braket{\hat{f}_{i},T[\mathbf{1}]}.= italic_C ⟨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T [ bold_1 ] end_ARG ⟩ . (56)

Then

(μi−μg)T⁢(μj−μg)superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝜇𝑔𝑇subscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔\displaystyle(\mu_{i}-\mu_{g})^{T}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =⟨C⁢f^i−𝟏,T⁢[C⁢f^j−𝟏]⟩absentexpectation𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑖1𝑇delimited-[]𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1\displaystyle=\braket{C\hat{f}_{i}-\mathbf{1},T[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]}= ⟨ start_ARG italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 , italic_T [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] end_ARG ⟩ (57)
=C⁢a2⁢(δi⁢j−1C)absent𝐶subscript𝑎2subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗1𝐶\displaystyle=Ca_{2}(\delta_{ij}-\frac{1}{C})= italic_C italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ) (58)

which is the NC2 condition, where we used Equation 49 and Equation 53 in the first line and Proposition 1 in the second line.  

See 2

Proof  Using the condition that χ𝜒\textstyle\chiitalic_χ is the training set, and q𝑞qitalic_q is its empirical distribution, and f^^𝑓\hat{f}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG a class indicator function, we obtain

N⁢C⁢1𝑁𝐶1\displaystyle NC1italic_N italic_C 1 =T⁢r⁢(∑i∑x∈Ai(hi⁢(x)−μi)⁢(hi⁢(x)−μi)T⁢∑j(μj−μg)⁢(μj−μg)T)absent𝑇𝑟subscript𝑖subscript𝑥subscript𝐴𝑖subscriptℎ𝑖𝑥subscript𝜇𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑥subscript𝜇𝑖𝑇subscript𝑗subscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔𝑇\displaystyle=Tr\left(\sum_{i}\sum_{x\in A_{i}}(h_{i}(x)-\mu_{i})(h_{i}(x)-\mu% _{i})^{T}\sum_{j}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})^{T}\right)= italic_T italic_r ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
