μiT⁢(μj−μg)=⟨C⁢f^i|T⁢[C⁢f^j−𝟏]⟩superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑇subscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔inner-product𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑇delimited-[]𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1\mu_{i}^{T}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})=\braket{C\hat{f}_{i}}{T[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}]}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ⟨ start_ARG italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_T [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] end_ARG ⟩ (60)

and from Equation 21 and Equation 20

Φ⁢(x)T⁢(μj−μg)=T⁢[C⁢f^j−𝟏]⁢(x).Φsuperscript𝑥𝑇subscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔𝑇delimited-[]𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗1𝑥\Phi(x)^{T}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})=T[C\hat{f}_{j}-\mathbf{1}](x).roman_Φ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_T [ italic_C over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_1 ] ( italic_x ) . (61)

Applying Proposition 1 into the two equations above, we obtain

(Φ⁢(x)−μi)T⁢(μj−μg)=a2⁢C⁢(f^j⁢(x)−δi⁢j).superscriptΦ𝑥subscript𝜇𝑖𝑇subscript𝜇𝑗subscript𝜇𝑔subscript𝑎2𝐶subscript^𝑓𝑗𝑥subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗(\Phi(x)-\mu_{i})^{T}(\mu_{j}-\mu_{g})=a_{2}C(\hat{f}_{j}(x)-\delta_{ij}).( roman_Φ ( italic_x ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C ( over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (62)

Plugging Equation 62 into Equation 59, we obtain

N⁢C⁢1𝑁𝐶1\displaystyle NC1italic_N italic_C 1 =a22⁢C2⁢∑i,j∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢(f^j⁢(x)−δi⁢j)2⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑xabsentsubscriptsuperscript𝑎22superscript𝐶2subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript^𝑓𝑗𝑥subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗2𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=a^{2}_{2}C^{2}\sum_{i,j}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)% \left(\hat{f}_{j}(x)-\delta_{ij}\right)^{2}q(x)dx= italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (63)
=a22⁢C2⁢∑i,j∫χf^i⁢(x)⁢(f^j⁢(x)⁢(1−2⁢δi⁢j)+δi⁢j)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑xabsentsubscriptsuperscript𝑎22superscript𝐶2subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝜒subscript^𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript^𝑓𝑗𝑥12subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=a^{2}_{2}C^{2}\sum_{i,j}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\hat{f}_{i}(x)% (\hat{f}_{j}(x)(1-2\delta_{ij})+\delta_{ij})q(x)dx= italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( 1 - 2 italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (64)
=a22⁢C⁢∑i,j(δi⁢j⁢(2−2⁢δi⁢j))absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑎22𝐶subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗22subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=a^{2}_{2}C\sum_{i,j}\left(\delta_{ij}(2-2\delta_{ij})\right)= italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2 - 2 italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) (65)
=0absent0\displaystyle=0= 0 (66)

where in the third line, we used ⟨f^i|f^j⟩=δi⁢j⁢C−1inner-productsubscript^𝑓𝑖subscript^𝑓𝑗subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗superscript𝐶1\braket{\hat{f}_{i}}{\hat{f}_{j}}=\delta_{ij}C^{-1}⟨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ = italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ⟨f^i|1⟩=C−1inner-productsubscript^𝑓𝑖1superscript𝐶1\braket{\hat{f}_{i}}{1}=C^{-1}⟨ start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG 1 end_ARG ⟩ = italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.  

G Experimental details

G.1 Architecture details

k×k𝑘𝑘k\times kitalic_k × italic_k Conv(⋅,⋅,⋅,⋅)⋅⋅⋅⋅(\cdot,\cdot,\cdot,\cdot)( ⋅ , ⋅ , ⋅ , ⋅ ) refers to the 2d convolutional module with a kernel of size k𝑘kitalic_kxk𝑘kitalic_k, and arguments within parenthesis refer to the input channel, output channel, stride, and padding respectively. Linear(⋅,⋅)⋅⋅(\cdot,\cdot)( ⋅ , ⋅ ) refers to the fully connected module with the arguments referring to input width and output width respectively. MaxPool(⋅,⋅,⋅)⋅⋅⋅(\cdot,\cdot,\cdot)( ⋅ , ⋅ , ⋅ ) refers to max pooling with the arguments as kernel size, stride, and padding respectively. Adaptive Avgpool(⋅,⋅)⋅⋅(\cdot,\cdot)( ⋅ , ⋅ ) refers to adaptive average pooling where arguments are the size of the image after pooling. The curved arrow refers to the skip connection (identity), and any modules that appear in the arrow are applied. BN refers to batch normalization and (BN, ReLU) refers to the application of batch normalization and ReLU in respective order. The definition of the term “layer” for each model is also provided.

G.2 Learning rate and hyperparameters

In our experiments, unless explicitly stated, SGD with a momentum of 0.9 and weight decay of 0.001 was used. Adam [Kingma and Ba, 2014] was used when the model did not converge with SGD. All models were trained for 200, 400, or 600 epochs: the earliest epoch that achieves above 99% training accuracy. For models trained for 200 epochs, a scheduler with 0.2 decay for every 60 epochs was used. For models that require 400 or more epochs, the scheduler was removed. If the model did not converge in 600 epochs or achieve below 99% training accuracy, it would be explicitly mentioned.

CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 were normalized to the mean of (0.4914, 0.4822, 0.4465) and standard deviation of (0.2023, 0.1994, 0.2010). For data augmentation, a random crop of 32 with padding of 4 and a random horizontal flip was used. No augmentation or whitening was applied to the MNIST dataset.

G.3 Loss

We use MSE loss with a centered one-hot vector (i.e. ∑icfi∗⁢(x)=0superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑖𝑥0\sum_{i}^{c}f^{*}_{i}(x)=0∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = 0 for all x∈χ𝑥𝜒x\in{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}italic_x ∈ italic_χ) as the C𝐶Citalic_C dimensional target function f∗:χ→ℝC:superscript𝑓→𝜒superscriptℝ𝐶f^{*}:{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{C}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_χ → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Before centering, we have scaled the f∗superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by a factor of 3 for CIFAR10 and MNIST; and by 10 for CIFAR100.

H Accuracy of approximation methods

In the main text, we proposed three main measures of features: quality Q∗superscript𝑄Q^{*}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, utility Q^^𝑄\hat{Q}over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG, and eigenvalues (or intensity) ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ. These measures require the true input distribution q𝑞qitalic_q, which we cannot access in practice. The approximation method for these measures was described in Section 2.5 – the Nyström method for approximating eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the Riemann sum for the inner product in q𝑞qitalic_q. In this section, we use empirical methods - where the true eigenfunctions and eigenvalues are known- to assess the validity of Nyström method in approximating eigenvalues and eigenfunctions. We also discuss why quality and utility were presented in a cumulative manner (Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*}roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Π^^Π\hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG) while the eigenvalues (ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) are presented directly.

H.1 The Nyström method

As discussed in Section 2.5, the Nyström method diagonalizes the empirical feature matrix Φ⁢(X)∈ℝp×nΦ𝑋superscriptℝ𝑝𝑛\Phi(X)\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times n}roman_Φ ( italic_X ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to approximate the eigenfunctions eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and eigenvalues ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is more explicitly written in lines 6 and 7 of Algorithm 1:

ρk←sk2,ek⁢(x)←ukT⁢Φ⁢(x)/sk,formulae-sequence←subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘2←subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑘𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝑠𝑘\rho_{k}\leftarrow s_{k}^{2},\quad\quad e_{k}(x)\leftarrow u_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)/s_% {k},italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ← italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ← italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) / italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (67)

where u𝑢uitalic_u and s𝑠sitalic_s are the left orthogonal matrix and singular values obtained from singular value decomposition of Φ⁢(X)Φ𝑋\Phi(X)roman_Φ ( italic_X ).

H.1.1 Experiment setup for testing Nyström method

The accuracy of the Nyström method depends on the accuracy of singular values (sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and left eigenvectors (uksubscript𝑢𝑘u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) of a random matrix (Φ⁢(X)Φ𝑋\Phi(X)roman_Φ ( italic_X )). To empirically assess the accuracy of the method, we will use p𝑝pitalic_p independent Gaussian random variables to sample our feature matrix. A power-law distribution with exponent α𝛼\alphaitalic_α will be used as the eigenvalues:

Φk⁢(x)∼ρk⁢𝒩⁢(0,1),ρk=k−α.formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptΦ𝑘𝑥subscript𝜌𝑘𝒩01subscript𝜌𝑘superscript𝑘𝛼\Phi_{k}(x)\sim\sqrt{\rho_{k}}\mathcal{N}(0,1),\quad\quad\rho_{k}=k^{-\alpha}.roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ∼ square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (68)

Gaussian random variables serve as valid features since the features are random variables - x∼qsimilar-to𝑥𝑞x\sim qitalic_x ∼ italic_q is a random variable, and eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a fixed map, thus ek⁢(x),subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥e_{k}(x),italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , x∼qsimilar-to𝑥𝑞x\sim qitalic_x ∼ italic_q is also a random variable - and are orthogonal to other eigenfunctions:

ek⁢(x):Zk∼𝒩⁢(0,1),⟨ei|ej⟩=12⁢π⁢∫Zi,ZjZi⁢Zj⁢e−12⁢(Zi2+Zj2)⁢𝑑Zi⁢𝑑Zj=δi⁢j.:subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝑍𝑘𝒩01inner-productsubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑒𝑗12𝜋subscriptsubscript𝑍𝑖subscript𝑍𝑗subscript𝑍𝑖subscript𝑍𝑗superscript𝑒12superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑗2differential-dsubscript𝑍𝑖differential-dsubscript𝑍𝑗subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗e_{k}(x):Z_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1),\quad\quad\braket{e_{i}}{e_{j}}=\frac{1}{2% \pi}\int_{Z_{i},Z_{j}}Z_{i}Z_{j}e^{-\frac{1}{2}(Z_{i}^{2}+Z_{j}^{2})}dZ_{i}dZ_% {j}=\delta_{ij}.italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) : italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ) , ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_π end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (69)

Eigenfunctions can also be expressed with ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ as

ek⁢(x)=okT⁢Φ⁢(x)/ρksubscript𝑒𝑘𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑘𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝜌𝑘e_{k}(x)=o_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)/\sqrt{\rho_{k}}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) / square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG (70)

where ok∈𝐩subscript𝑜𝑘𝐩o_{k}\in\mathbf{p}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ bold_p is one-hot vector with its kt⁢hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry equal to 1111 and all other entries 00 (i.e. ok=[0,⋯,0,1,0,⋯,0]subscript𝑜𝑘0⋯010⋯0o_{k}=[0,\cdots,0,1,0,\cdots,0]italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ 0 , ⋯ , 0 , 1 , 0 , ⋯ , 0 ]). Indeed we can check that eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the eigenfunction of T𝑇Titalic_T with eigenvalue ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

T⁢[okT⁢Φ⁢(x)ρk]𝑇delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑘𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝜌𝑘\displaystyle T[\frac{o_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)}{\sqrt{\rho_{k}}}]italic_T [ divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ] =∫Φ⁢(x′)T⁢Φ⁢(x)⁢okT⁢Φ⁢(x)ρk⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑xabsentΦsuperscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑇Φ𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑘𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝜌𝑘𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=\int\Phi(x^{\prime})^{T}\Phi(x)\frac{o_{k}^{T}\Phi(x)}{\sqrt{% \rho_{k}}}q(x)dx= ∫ roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (71)
=Φ⁢(x′)T⁢∫Zk2⁢ρk2⁢π⁢e−Zk22⁢𝑑ZkabsentΦsuperscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘2subscript𝜌𝑘2𝜋superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘22differential-dsubscript𝑍𝑘\displaystyle=\Phi(x^{\prime})^{T}\int Z_{k}^{2}\sqrt{\frac{\rho_{k}}{2\pi}}e^% {-\frac{Z_{k}^{2}}{2}}dZ_{k}= roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_π end_ARG end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (72)
=ρk⁢Φ⁢(x′)T⁢okabsentsubscript𝜌𝑘Φsuperscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑇subscript𝑜𝑘\displaystyle=\sqrt{\rho_{k}}\Phi(x^{\prime})^{T}o_{k}= square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (73)
=ρk⁢ek,absentsubscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘\displaystyle=\rho_{k}e_{k},= italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (74)

where in the second line, we used that okTsubscriptsuperscript𝑜𝑇𝑘o^{T}_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a one-hot vector.

H.1.2 Accuracy measures

With the underlying true features and eigenvalues defined, we propose measures for calculating the accuracy of approximated values obtained via Algorithm 1.

The error of eigenvalue is measured as square distance between ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (true value) and sk2⁢(X)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘2𝑋s_{k}^{2}(X)italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X ) (approximation) normalized by ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

EX⁢[(sk2⁢(X)−ρk)2ρk2],subscriptE𝑋delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘2𝑋subscript𝜌𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑘2\mathrm{E}_{X}\left[\frac{(s_{k}^{2}(X)-\rho_{k})^{2}}{\rho_{k}^{2}}\right],roman_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X ) - italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] , (75)

Note that EX⁢[]subscriptE𝑋\mathrm{E}_{X}[]roman_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ] means expectation over all possible features matrices Φ⁢(X)Φ𝑋\Phi(X)roman_Φ ( italic_X ).

The error of eigenfunction is measured as 1111 minus the inner product between uk⁢(X)∈ℝpsubscript𝑢𝑘𝑋superscriptℝ𝑝u_{k}(X)\in\mathbb{R}^{p}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and oksubscript𝑜𝑘o_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

1−𝐄X⁢[|ukT⁢ok|].1subscript𝐄𝑋delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑘𝑇subscript𝑜𝑘1-\mathbf{E}_{X}\left[|u_{k}^{T}o_{k}|\right].1 - bold_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ | italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ] . (76)

The inner product ukT⁢oksuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑘𝑇subscript𝑜𝑘u_{k}^{T}o_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is proportional to the inner product between eka⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢xsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥e_{k}^{approx}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

⟨eka⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x,ek⟩expectationsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥subscript𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\braket{e_{k}^{approx},e_{k}}⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ =∫(uk⁢(X)T⁢Φ⁢(x)sk⁢(X))T⁢okT⁢Φ⁢(x)ρk⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑xabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑘superscript𝑋𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝑠𝑘𝑋𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑜𝑘𝑇Φ𝑥subscript𝜌𝑘𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=\int\left(\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}\Phi(x)}{s_{k}(X)}\right)^{T}\frac{o% _{k}^{T}\Phi(x)}{\sqrt{\rho_{k}}}q(x)dx= ∫ ( divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (77)
=uk⁢(X)Tsk⁢(X)⁢∫Φ⁢(x)T⁢Φ⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x⁢okρkabsentsubscript𝑢𝑘superscript𝑋𝑇subscript𝑠𝑘𝑋Φsuperscript𝑥𝑇Φ𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥subscript𝑜𝑘subscript𝜌𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}}{s_{k}(X)}\int\Phi(x)^{T}\Phi(x)q(x)dx\frac{o% _{k}}{\sqrt{\rho_{k}}}= divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) end_ARG ∫ roman_Φ ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG (78)
=uk⁢(X)Tsk⁢(X)⁢D⁢i⁢a⁢g⁢(ρk)⁢okρkabsentsubscript𝑢𝑘superscript𝑋𝑇subscript𝑠𝑘𝑋𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑔subscript𝜌𝑘subscript𝑜𝑘subscript𝜌𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}}{s_{k}(X)}Diag(\rho_{k})\frac{o_{k}}{\sqrt{% \rho_{k}}}= divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) end_ARG italic_D italic_i italic_a italic_g ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG (79)
=uk⁢(X)T⁢oksk⁢(X)⁢ρk,absentsubscript𝑢𝑘superscript𝑋𝑇subscript𝑜𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘𝑋subscript𝜌𝑘\displaystyle=\frac{u_{k}(X)^{T}o_{k}}{s_{k}(X)\sqrt{\rho_{k}}},= divide start_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) square-root start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG , (80)

where the denominator is not of interest as we are not particularly interested in the norm of the eka⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢xsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥𝑘e^{approx}_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

H.1.3 Results

In Figure 27 we generate a feature matrix containing n=10,000𝑛10000n=10,000italic_n = 10 , 000 datapoints and p=1000𝑝1000p=1000italic_p = 1000 features with Gaussian random variables. We use the Nyström method to approximate the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions and assess their accuracy with the metrics in Equation 75 and Equation 76. We observe in Figure 27(a) that eigenvalues are approximated precisely except for eigenvalues with k≈p𝑘𝑝k\approx pitalic_k ≈ italic_p. In Figure 27(b), we observe that the accuracy of the eigenfunctions correlates with the respective eigenvalues: the larger the eigenvalue (compared to the median eigenvalue), the better the accuracy. In the main text, we are often interested only in the first few eigenfunctions with large eigenvalues; We can conclude that the Nyström method is sufficiently accurate for our needs.

H.2 Function space approximation

The Nyström method’s prediction accuracy degrades for smaller eigenvalues. The spanned space of [e1a⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x,⋯,eka⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x]superscriptsubscript𝑒1𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥⋯superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥[e_{1}^{approx},\cdots,e_{k}^{approx}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], however, often accurately approximates that of [e1,⋯,ek]subscript𝑒1⋯subscript𝑒𝑘[e_{1},\cdots,e_{k}][ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]; The larger error of the eka⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢xsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥e_{k}^{approx}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is often due to the cumulation of error in predicting ei<ka⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢xsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑘𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥e_{i<k}^{approx}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i < italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Figure 28 illustrates an example where [u1,u2,u3]subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2subscript𝑢3[u_{1},u_{2},u_{3}][ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] span the same space as [o1,o2,o3]subscript𝑜1subscript𝑜2subscript𝑜3[o_{1},o_{2},o_{3}][ italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], and u1subscript𝑢1u_{1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (thus e1subscript𝑒1e_{1}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and e2subscript𝑒2e_{2}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) are well approximated – the errors in predicting u1subscript𝑢1u_{1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT accumulate to the error of predicting u3subscript𝑢3u_{3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and results in a poorer approximation for u3subscript𝑢3u_{3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We can use the Gaussian random variable setup to check the error of the function space approximation. To measure the similarity between s⁢p⁢a⁢n⁢([e1,⋯,ek])𝑠𝑝𝑎𝑛subscript𝑒1⋯subscript𝑒𝑘span([e_{1},\cdots,e_{k}])italic_s italic_p italic_a italic_n ( [ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) and approximated function space [e1a⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x,⋯,eka⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x]subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥1⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥𝑘[e^{approx}_{1},\cdots,e^{approx}_{k}][ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], we can use k-SVCCA [Raghu et al., 2017] or the cumulative projection measure in Equation 9.

1k⁢∑i=1k∑j=1k⟨ei|eja⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⟩2.1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘superscriptinner-productsubscript𝑒𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥2\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\braket{e_{i}}{e_{j}^{approx}}^{2}.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (81)

Since we can express the inner product between true and approximated eigenfunctions with uksubscript𝑢𝑘u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and oksubscript𝑜𝑘o_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Equation 77), we can express the metric in terms of uksubscript𝑢𝑘u_{k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and oksubscript𝑜𝑘o_{k}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

1−1k⁢∑i=1k∑j=1k(uiT⁢oj)2,11𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑇subscript𝑜𝑗21-\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\sum_{j=1}^{k}\left(u_{i}^{T}o_{j}\right)^{2},1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (82)

where we subtracted the measure from 1 so the measure will be 00 when there is no error. In Figure 27(c), we observe that the function space can be approximated more accurately in comparison to individual eigenfunctions in Figure 27(b); This is why we often present the quality and utility in cumulative measure Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*}roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or Π^^Π\hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG.

H.3 Error in projection measures

We now discuss the error in the projection measures like Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*}roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The projection measure (Equation 7) consists of the sum of squares of inner products between eigenfunctions and function of interest (target or expressed). The Riemann sum over the test set approximates the inner product – similar to how test loss approximates generalization loss.

⟨ek,fj⟩2‖ek‖22⁢‖fj‖22=(∫χek⁢(x)⁢fj⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x)2∫χek⁢(x)2⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x⁢∫χfj⁢(x)2⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x≈(∑x(i)∈St⁢eek⁢(x(i))⁢fj⁢(x(i)))2∑x(i)∈St⁢eek⁢(x(i))2⁢∑x(i)∈St⁢efj⁢(x(i))2.superscriptexpectationsubscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑓𝑗2subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscript𝑒𝑘22subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscript𝑓𝑗22superscriptsubscript𝜒subscript𝑒𝑘𝑥subscript𝑓𝑗𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥2subscript𝜒subscript𝑒𝑘superscript𝑥2𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥subscript𝜒subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝑥2𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑡𝑒subscript𝑒𝑘superscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝑥𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑡𝑒subscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑆𝑡𝑒subscript𝑓𝑗superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑖2\frac{\braket{e_{k},f_{j}}^{2}}{\|e_{k}\|^{2}_{2}\|f_{j}\|^{2}_{2}}=\frac{% 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (83)

Using the Riemann sum, we can measure the correlation between spanned spaces (Equation 9). Using the vector representation of eigenfunction in the test set eia⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⁢(Xt⁢e⁢s⁢t)∈ℝnt⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥𝑖subscript𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡superscriptℝsubscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡e^{approx}_{i}(X_{test})\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{test}}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the vector representation of function of interest fi⁢(Xt⁢e⁢s⁢t)subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡f_{i}(X_{test})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we can approximate Equation 9 as

∑j=1C∑i=1p⟨ei|fj⟩2≈Tr(EFTFET),Ei⁢j=eia⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⁢(x(j))∑jnEi⁢j2,Fi⁢j=fi⁢(x(j))∑jnFi⁢j2.\sum_{j=1}^{C}\sum_{i=1}^{p}\braket{e_{i}}{f_{j}}^{2}\approx\mathrm{Tr}(EF^{T}% FE^{T})\quad\quad,E_{ij}=\frac{e^{approx}_{i}(x^{(j)})}{\sum_{j}^{n}E_{ij}^{2}% },\quad\ F_{ij}=\frac{f_{i}(x^{(j)})}{{\sum_{j}^{n}F_{ij}^{2}}}.∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≈ roman_Tr ( italic_E italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (84)

where x(j)superscript𝑥𝑗x^{(j)}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are iterated over the test set. If the rows of E∈ℝp×nt⁢e⁢s⁢t𝐸superscriptℝ𝑝subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡E\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times n_{test}}italic_E ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and F∈ℝC×nt⁢e⁢s⁢t𝐹superscriptℝ𝐶subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡F\in\mathbb{R}^{C\times n_{test}}italic_F ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C × italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are orthogonal, then Equation 84 is smaller than equal to 1111: consistent with the definition of Equation 9.

However, Equation 84 is susceptible to error when: rows of E𝐸Eitalic_E are not orthogonal and when p≈nt⁢e⁢s⁢t𝑝subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡p\approx n_{test}italic_p ≈ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We will discuss how we handled such problems in the paper.

H.3.1 Non orthogonal eigenfunctions

As discussed earlier, approximated eigenfunctions are less accurate when their eigenvalues are smaller; they may not even be orthogonal in q𝑞qitalic_q or the empirical distribution of the test set. The inner product between two approximated eigenfunctions is

⟨eia⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x|eja⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⟩inner-productsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥\displaystyle\braket{e_{i}^{approx}}{e_{j}^{approx}}⟨ start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⟩ =1si⁢sj⁢∫χuiT⁢Φ⁢(x)⁢ΦT⁢(x)⁢uj⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑xabsent1subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑠𝑗subscript𝜒superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑇Φ𝑥superscriptΦ𝑇𝑥subscript𝑢𝑗𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=\frac{1}{s_{i}s_{j}}\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}u_{i}^{T}\Phi(% x)\Phi^{T}(x)u_{j}q(x)dx= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x (85)
=1si⁢sj⁢uiT⁢(∫χΦ⁢(x)⁢ΦT⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑x)⁢ujabsent1subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑠𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑇subscript𝜒Φ𝑥superscriptΦ𝑇𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥subscript𝑢𝑗\displaystyle=\frac{1}{s_{i}s_{j}}u_{i}^{T}\left(\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0% .0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0% pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)% \Phi^{T}(x)q(x)dx\right)u_{j}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x ) italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (86)
=1si⁢sj⁢uiT⁢J⁢uj,absent1subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑠𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑇𝐽subscript𝑢𝑗\displaystyle=\frac{1}{s_{i}s_{j}}u_{i}^{T}Ju_{j},= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (87)

where the Fisher information matrix J∈ℝp×p𝐽superscriptℝ𝑝𝑝J\in\mathbb{R}^{p\times p}italic_J ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [Karakida et al., 2021] is defined as ∫χΦ⁢(x)⁢ΦT⁢(x)⁢q⁢(x)⁢𝑑xsubscript𝜒Φ𝑥superscriptΦ𝑇𝑥𝑞𝑥differential-d𝑥\int_{\mathchoice{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\displaystyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \textstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$\scriptstyle\chi$}}{\raisebox{0.0pt}{$% \scriptscriptstyle\chi$}}}\Phi(x)\Phi^{T}(x)q(x)dx∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_χ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ ( italic_x ) roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_q ( italic_x ) italic_d italic_x. Equation 85 equals Kronecker delta if only if [u1,⋯,up]subscript𝑢1⋯subscript𝑢𝑝[u_{1},\cdots,u_{p}][ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are the eigenvectors of J𝐽Jitalic_J with eigenvalues [s12,⋯,sp2]superscriptsubscript𝑠12⋯superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑝2[s_{1}^{2},\cdots,s_{p}^{2}][ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]. Since we obtained uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the empirical feature matrix of the training set, the approximated eigenfunctions, especially those with small eigenvalues, are often not orthogonal in q𝑞qitalic_q (and in the test set).

To handle such an issue, we use QR decomposition on E=[e1a⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⁢(Xt⁢e⁢s⁢t),⋯,epa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⁢(Xt⁢e⁢s⁢t)]∈ℝp×nt⁢e⁢s⁢t𝐸subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥1subscript𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥𝑝subscript𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡superscriptℝ𝑝subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡E=[e^{approx}_{1}(X_{test}),\cdots,e^{approx}_{p}(X_{test})]\in\mathbb{R}^{p% \times n_{test}}italic_E = [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ⋯ , italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p × italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT before applying Equation 84: because QR decomposition orthogonalizes the rows; preserves the span of the first k𝑘kitalic_k vectors; handles overlapping vector between rows by conserving larger eigenvalue eigenvectors (eigenfunctions) - which are more accurate.

In Figure 29, we plot the cumulative measure with and without QR decomposition for ResNet18 on CIFAR10. We observe that Π∗superscriptΠ\Pi^{*}roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Π^^Π\hat{\Pi}over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG grow beyond 1111 without QR decomposition, indicating that approximated eigenfunctions are not orthogonal; The inconsistent behaviour is removed when QR decomposition is applied. Note that the deviation between QR and no-QR plots emerges when the eigenvalues are sufficiently small (larger error in approximating the eigenfunction).

H.3.2 Finite size effect

For two sets of basis functions, increasing the number of bases to a large but finite value does not guarantee any overlap between the two function spaces: because functions are infinite-dimensional vectors. This is not the case for two finite-dimensional matrices: If p=nt⁢e⁢s⁢t𝑝subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡p=n_{test}italic_p = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation 84 and E𝐸Eitalic_E has full rank, then any F𝐹Fitalic_F will be spanned by the rows of E𝐸Eitalic_E.

In Figure 29(a,b), we observe that Π∗⁢(nt⁢e⁢s⁢t)superscriptΠsubscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡\Pi^{*}(n_{test})roman_Π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Π^⁢(nt⁢e⁢s⁢t)^Πsubscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡\hat{\Pi}(n_{test})over^ start_ARG roman_Π end_ARG ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are equal to 1111 for layers with p>nt⁢e⁢s⁢t𝑝subscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡p>n_{test}italic_p > italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This does not indicate that intermediate features can express the target/expressed function; It is achieved because nt⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡n_{test}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT orthogonal vectors (E𝐸Eitalic_E) can always span nt⁢e⁢s⁢tsubscript𝑛𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡n_{test}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t italic_e italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT dimensional vector space (and thus the row space of F𝐹Fitalic_F).

Report Github Issue
Generated by L A T E xml

Instructions for reporting errors

We are continuing to improve HTML versions of papers, and your feedback helps enhance accessibility and mobile support. To report errors in the HTML that will help us improve conversion and rendering, choose any of the methods listed below:

  • Click the "Report Issue" button.
  • Open a report feedback form via keyboard, use "Ctrl + ?".
  • Make a text selection and click the "Report Issue for Selection" button near your cursor.
  • You can use Alt+Y to toggle on and Alt+Shift+Y to toggle off accessible reporting links at each section.

Our team has already identified the following issues. We appreciate your time reviewing and reporting rendering errors we may not have found yet. Your efforts will help us improve the HTML versions for all readers, because disability should not be a barrier to accessing research. Thank you for your continued support in championing open access for all.

Have a free development cycle? Help support accessibility at arXiv! Our collaborators at LaTeXML maintain a list of packages that need conversion, and welcome developer contributions.
